\frac{I_r}{I_0} &= \frac{2}{49}\Bigl[\,1 - \cos\Bigl(\frac{4\pi n d}{\lambda}\Bigr)\Bigr],\\[1mm]
I_{\text{max}} &= \frac{4}{49} I_0 \approx 0.082\, I_0,\quad I_{\text{min}} = 0.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We begin by recalling that a circularly‐polarized photon carries spin angular momentum of magnitude ħ. (Its sign depends on handedness, but here we are concerned with the magnitude of the transferred angular momentum.) In our problem the light is defined as right‐handed (clockwise when looking toward the oncoming beam) and the transfer of spin by the light is to be measured via the torque exerted on the slab.

A key point is that when a photon is “used” in a process (whether by being absorbed, reflected, or having its polarization changed) the difference between its initial and final spin angular momentum is what must be delivered (or taken) by the medium.

Also note that 1 watt = 10⁷ erg/s and 
  c = 3×10¹⁰ cm/s,
and the wavelength is
  λ = 6200 Å = 6200×10^(–8) cm = 6.2×10^(–5) cm.

Let’s now analyze each case step by step.

────────────────────────────
Step 1. Angular momentum per second carried by the light

The energy of one photon is 
  E = ħω  with ω = 2πc/λ.
Thus the number of photons arriving per second is

  n = P/(ħω) = P/[ħ(2πc/λ)] = (Pλ)/(2πcħ).

When a photon transfers “Δ” spin angular momentum, then the total angular momentum transferred per unit time (which is a torque) is

  τ = n (Δ)

For our purpose we shall define τ₀ as the torque when each photon transfers an angular momentum of ħ (that is, if the entire photon is absorbed and its spin is taken up by the slab). Then

  τ₀ = nħ = (Pλ)/(2πc). 

Plugging in the numbers gives

  τ₀ = (10⁷ erg/s × 6.2×10^(–5) cm) / (2π×3×10^(10) cm/s).

Let us calculate the numerator first:
  10⁷ × 6.2×10^(–5) = 6.2×10² erg·cm/s = 620 erg·cm/s.

The denominator is
  2π×3×10¹⁰ ≈ 6.2832×3×10¹⁰ ≈ 1.88496×10¹¹.

Thus

  τ₀ ≈ 620 / (1.88496×10¹¹) dyne-cm ≈ 3.29×10^(–9) dyne-cm.

We now consider the four cases.

────────────────────────────
(a) Absorbing slab

If the slab is completely absorbing all the light, each photon disappears and its spin angular momentum (with magnitude ħ) is completely transferred. Thus the torque is exactly

  τ₀ = Pλ/(2πc) ≈ 3.3×10^(–9) dyne-cm.

────────────────────────────
(b) Ordinary Silvered Mirror

When light is reflected, the polarization is reversed. (For conventional metallic mirrors an incident circularly‐polarized photon, say RCP with spin +ħ, is reflected as LCP with spin –ħ.) Hence the change per photon is

  Δ = (–ħ) – (+ħ) = –2ħ   (i.e. a change in magnitude of 2ħ).

Thus the mirror must supply (or absorb) twice as much angular momentum per photon compared to the absorption case. Hence the torque is

  τ = 2τ₀.

In units of τ₀, the answer is 2.

────────────────────────────
(c) Transparent Half‐wave Plate

A half‐wave plate is designed to flip the handedness of circularly–polarized light. That is, a right‐circularly–polarized (RCP) photon (spin +ħ) becomes left‐circularly–polarized (LCP, spin –ħ) upon transmission. So each photon’s spin changes by

  Δ = (–ħ) – (+ħ) = –2ħ.

Again, the magnitude of the change is 2ħ per photon. Therefore, the rate of angular momentum transferred (torque) is again

  τ = 2τ₀.

Thus in units of τ₀ the answer is 2.

────────────────────────────
(d) Transparent Half‐wave Plate with the Top Surface Silvered

Now the light undergoes a two‐step process:
 1. It enters the half–wave plate from below. On first passage the half–wave plate flips RCP into LCP. (Angular momentum change: –2ħ per photon; the plate takes –2ħ per photon.)
 2. The LCP light then meets the silvered (mirror) top surface and is reflected. As before, reflection flips LCP back to RCP, so the mirror gives a change Δ = [(+ħ) – (–ħ)] = +2ħ. 
 3. The RCP light then passes back down through the half–wave plate. On this second pass the half–wave plate again flips the polarization: RCP becomes LCP, contributing another –2ħ per photon.

Thus, the net change in the photon’s spin going from the initial RCP to the final state is

  (First pass: –2ħ) + (Mirror: +2ħ) + (Second pass: –2ħ) = –2ħ.

That is, overall, each photon suffers a total change of 2ħ in magnitude (the sign indicates the direction, but here we are asked for the magnitude in terms of τ₀). Therefore, the net torque on the entire slab (half–wave plate plus mirror) is

  τ = 2τ₀.

It is interesting to note that although the half–wave plate itself undergoes two passes (and so feels torques on each pass), the total angular momentum change delivered to the slab is the same as in part (b) and (c).

────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The torque is
  τ₀ = Pλ/(2πc) ≈ 3.3×10^(–9) dyne-cm.

(b) For a silvered mirror, the torque is 2τ₀.

(c) For a transparent half–wave plate the torque is 2τ₀.

(d) For a transparent half–wave plate with the top surface silvered the torque is also 2τ₀.

Thus, in boxed final answer form we have:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad \tau_0 &= \frac{P\lambda}{2\pi c} \approx 3.3\times10^{-9}\,{\rm dyne\!-\!cm},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad \tau &= 2\,\tau_0,\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad \tau &= 2\,\tau_0,\\[1mm]
\text{(d)}\quad \tau &= 2\,\tau_0.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We want the intensity produced by two slits of unequal width when illuminated by a plane‐wave (wavelength λ) in the Fraunhofer region. One slit has width a and the other width b. Their centers are separated by a distance c. For convenience, we imagine placing the coordinate system so that the centers of the two slits lie at y = –c/2 and y = +c/2.

Below we describe the step‐by‐step derivation and then discuss two special cases.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Amplitude from a Single Slit

For a single slit of width d (d = a or b), the amplitude at an angle θ is proportional to the integral
  A(d,θ) ∝ ∫ from –(d/2) to d/2 e^(ik y sin θ) dy,
where k = 2π/λ. Evaluating the integral (a standard calculation) one obtains
  A(d,θ) ∝ d ⋅ sinc(β),
with
  β = π d sinθ/λ          (sinc(x) ≡ sin x/x).

Thus, for a slit of width a we have
  A_a(θ) ∝ a⋅sinc(π a sinθ/λ),
and similarly for width b:
  A_b(θ) ∝ b⋅sinc(π b sinθ/λ).

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Including the Position-dependent Phase

Because the slits are not at the same position, a phase factor must be included. With the centers at y = –c/2 and y = +c/2, the two amplitudes acquire the phase factors respectively:

• For the slit at y = –c/2:
  A_a(θ) ∝ a⋅sinc(π a sinθ/λ)⋅exp[–i k (c/2) sinθ].

• For the slit at y = +c/2:
  A_b(θ) ∝ b⋅sinc(π b sinθ/λ)⋅exp[+i k (c/2) sinθ].

Thus, the resultant total amplitude is
  A_total(θ) ∝ a⋅sinc(π a sinθ/λ) e^(–iπc sinθ/λ)
       + b⋅sinc(π b sinθ/λ) e^(+iπc sinθ/λ),
since k = 2π/λ.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Intensity Calculation

The intensity is proportional to the square of the modulus of the total amplitude:
  I(θ) ∝ |A_total(θ)|².

A little algebra gives
  I(θ) ∝ [a⋅sinc(π a sinθ/λ)]² + [b⋅sinc(π b sinθ/λ)]²
      + 2ab⋅sinc(π a sinθ/λ)⋅sinc(π b sinθ/λ) cos(2πc sinθ/λ).

It is sometimes convenient to introduce the notations
  α = (π a sinθ)/λ,  β = (π b sinθ)/λ,  and δ = (π c sinθ)/λ,
so that the expression becomes
  I(θ) ∝ a² sinc²(α) + b² sinc²(β) + 2ab sinc(α)sinc(β) cos(2δ).

This is the general answer for two unequal slits.

──────────────────────────────
(a) Final expression

Thus, the intensity pattern for any diffraction angle θ is
  I(θ) ∝ [a sinc(π a sinθ/λ)]² + [b sinc(π b sinθ/λ)]² + 2ab sinc(π a sinθ/λ) sinc(π b sinθ/λ) cos(2π c sinθ/λ).

──────────────────────────────
(b) Special Cases

(1) Case: a = b

When the two slits have equal widths (let a = b = d),
  A_total(θ) ∝ d sinc(π d sinθ/λ)[e^(–iπc sinθ/λ) + e^(+iπc sinθ/λ)].
But note that
  e^(–iπc sinθ/λ) + e^(+iπc sinθ/λ) = 2 cos(πc sinθ/λ).

Thus the amplitude becomes
  A_total(θ) ∝ 2d sinc(π d sinθ/λ) cos(πc sinθ/λ),
so that
  I(θ) ∝ 4d² sinc²(π d sinθ/λ) cos²(πc sinθ/λ).

Sketch: The pattern shows a single‐slit diffraction envelope (given by sinc²) modulated by the more rapid oscillations (cos²) due to the interference between the two slits. The central maximum is very bright and the intensity drops off in the familiar pattern with secondary maxima and minima.

(2) Case: a = 0

When one slit is “closed” (a = 0), there is no contribution from the first slit. Only the slit of width b remains, so the intensity is
  I(θ) ∝ [b sinc(π b sinθ/λ)]².

Sketch: This is merely the usual single‐slit diffraction pattern for a slit of width b.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

Thus, our complete answers are:

For (a):
  I(θ) ∝ [a sinc(π a sinθ/λ)]² + [b sinc(π b sinθ/λ)]² + 2ab sinc(π a sinθ/λ)sinc(π b sinθ/λ) cos(2π c sinθ/λ).

For (b):
  (1) When a = b = d,
   I(θ) ∝ 4d² sinc²(π d sinθ/λ) cos²(πc sinθ/λ);
  (2) When a = 0,
   I(θ) ∝ b² sinc²(π b sinθ/λ).

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in boxed LaTeX

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad I(\theta)&\propto \left[a\,\frac{\sin\Bigl(\frac{\pi a\sin\theta}{\lambda}\Bigr)}{\frac{\pi a\sin\theta}{\lambda}}\right]^2
+\left[b\,\frac{\sin\Bigl(\frac{\pi b\sin\theta}{\lambda}\Bigr)}{\frac{\pi b\sin\theta}{\lambda}}\right]^2\\[1mm]
&\quad\quad+2ab\,\frac{\sin\Bigl(\frac{\pi a\sin\theta}{\lambda}\Bigr)}{\frac{\pi a\sin\theta}{\lambda}}
\frac{\sin\Bigl(\frac{\pi b\sin\theta}{\lambda}\Bigr)}{\frac{\pi b\sin\theta}{\lambda}}
\cos\Bigl(\frac{2\pi c\sin\theta}{\lambda}\Bigr). \\[2mm]
\text{(b)}\quad \text{(1) For } a=b=d:\quad & I(\theta)\propto 4d^2\,\operatorname{sinc}^2\!\left(\frac{\pi d\sin\theta}{\lambda}\right)\cos^2\!\left(\frac{\pi c\sin\theta}{\lambda}\right),\\[1mm]
\quad \text{(2) For } a=0:\quad & I(\theta)\propto b^2\,\operatorname{sinc}^2\!\left(\frac{\pi b\sin\theta}{\lambda}\right).
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We can begin by noticing that the effect in question is a manifestation of optical activity.

Step 1. (What is the phenomenon?)  
This phenomenon is called "optical rotation" observed in optically active media. In such crystals, the refractive indices for right- and left-circularly polarized light (n_R and n_L respectively) are slightly different. When plane-polarized light (which can be considered as a superposition of equal-amplitude right and left circularly polarized waves) enters the crystal, the two circular components propagate at different speeds. As a result, they accumulate different phases while traveling through the medium. When these two components are recombined at the exit, the net result is that the plane of polarization has rotated relative to its original orientation. This is because the relative phase shift between the two circular components determines the angle of the resultant linear polarization.

Step 2. (Derivation of the rotation angle φ)  
Consider plane-polarized light of angular frequency ω entering the material of thickness d. The plane-polarized wave may be written as a sum of right- and left-circularly polarized components. These components travel with different wave numbers:
  k_R = (n_R ω)/c  and  k_L = (n_L ω)/c,  
where c is the speed of light in vacuum.

Over the thickness d, the right- and left-circular components accumulate different phase shifts:
  Phase for R: k_R d = (ω n_R d)/c,
  Phase for L: k_L d = (ω n_L d)/c.

Thus, the phase difference between the two components is:
  Δφ = k_R d − k_L d = (ω d/c)(n_R − n_L).

Since the original plane-polarized light was an equal superposition of these two circular modes, the polarization rotates by half of the phase difference between them. Therefore, the rotation angle φ is given by:
  φ = Δφ/2 = (ω d/(2c)) (n_R − n_L).

Final answer:
  \[
\boxed{\phi = \frac{\omega d}{2c}(n_R - n_L)}
\]

We start with a 60 mm lens focused at s = 15 m. In order to see a star (at infinity) sharply, the sensor would need to be at the precise image plane for infinity, which is at the focal length f = 60 mm. However, the sensor is set slightly farther away (at the image distance for 15 m objects) so that when imaging a star the image is defocused. Our goal is to choose an aperture such that the defocus blur (geometric blur) is about equal to the diffraction blur (Airy disk) for visible light.

Step 1. Find the image distance for an object at 15 m using the lens equation

  1/s + 1/s′ = 1/f

For s = 15 m and f = 0.06 m:

  1/s′ = 1/f − 1/s = (1/0.06) − (1/15)
     = 16.67 m⁻¹ − 0.0667 m⁻¹ ≈ 16.60 m⁻¹

So,  s′ ≈ 1/16.60 ≈ 0.06024 m.

The sensor is therefore behind the lens at about 60.24 mm. For an object at infinity the best focus is at 60.00 mm, so the defocus error is

  δ = s′ (for 15 m) − f = 0.06024 m − 0.06 m ≈ 0.00024 m.

Step 2. Determine the defocus blur circle

For a lens with aperture diameter D, a simple geometric argument shows that when the sensor is mis‐positioned by an amount δ, the blur circle has a diameter approximately

  d_defocus ≈ (D/f)·δ.

Step 3. Determine the diffraction blur (Airy disk)

For a circular aperture the diameter of the first dark ring (first minimum) of the Airy pattern (which we take as a measure of the diffraction blur) is

  d_diffraction ≈ 2.44 λ (f/D),

where λ is a typical wavelength of visible light. (A commonly used value is λ = 550 nm = 550×10⁻⁹ m.)

Step 4. Equate defocus and diffraction blur diameters

We wish to have

  d_defocus = d_diffraction,
   (D/f)·δ = 2.44 λ (f/D).

Solve for D:
  Multiply both sides by D:
    (D²/f)·δ = 2.44 λ f,
  So,
    D² = (2.44 λ f²)/δ.

Step 5. Insert the numerical values

  f = 0.06 m,
  δ = 0.00024 m,
  λ = 550×10⁻⁹ m.

Compute the numerator:
  2.44 λ = 2.44 × 550×10⁻⁹ m ≈ 1.342×10⁻⁶ m,
Then,
  D² = (1.342×10⁻⁶ m × (0.06 m)²) / 0.00024 m.
First, (0.06 m)² = 0.0036 m², so:
  D² = (1.342×10⁻⁶ m × 0.0036 m²) / 0.00024 m
     = (4.83×10⁻⁹ m³) / 0.00024 m
     ≈ 2.0125×10⁻⁵ m².

Taking the square root,
  D ≈ √(2.0125×10⁻⁵ m²) ≈ 0.00449 m, i.e. about 4.5 mm.

Step 6. Interpret in terms of f‐number

The f-number is given by f/D. With f = 60 mm and D ≈ 4.5 mm, we have

  f/number ≈ 60 mm / 4.5 mm ≈ 13.3,
i.e. approximately f/13.

Final Answer:
For the diffraction blur to be roughly equal to the defocus blur (when the lens is focused at 15 m and imaging a star at infinity), the aperture opening should be about 4.5 mm in diameter, which is approximately f/13 on a 60 mm lens.

\[
\boxed{\text{Aperture diameter } \approx 4.5\,\text{mm}\text{ (about f/13)}}
\]

solution:
We will show that when one “opens‐up” (or “closes”) a circular region of an otherwise totally opaque screen, the light measured on axis does not rise monotonically from zero (for a very small “hole”) to the full “open‐field” value (when the whole wave–front is transmitted) but rather overshoots and oscillates. One acceptable answer is as follows.

In the Fresnel (paraxial) approximation one may show that the complex amplitude on axis provided by the light coming through a circular aperture (hole) of radius r is, apart from a trivial overall phase factor, given by

  (1)  U(r) ∝ 1 – exp[i φ(r)]   with  φ(r)=πr²/(λL).

(To obtain this one “integrates” over a circular region; the fact that the phase at a point a distance ρ from the geometrical centre is (approximately) kρ²/(2L) leads to the phase φ(r)=πr²/(λL) after writing k=2π/λ.)

Thus the on‐axis intensity is
  (2)  I(r) ∝ |1 – e^(i φ(r))|² = 2 – 2 cos[φ(r)]
or, equivalently,
  (3)  I(r) ∝ 4 sin²(φ(r)/2).

Now, one “normalizes” the full–open intensity (when the hole is arbitrarily large) to be unity. (In our Fresnel–Kirchhoff treatment the “full‐field” amplitude is not 1 but is reached in the limit of very large r; one may always rescale so that I(∞)=1.) With that normalization the answers below follow.

Let us now answer the four parts.

–––––––––––––––
Part (a). First maximum

The intensity (3) oscillates as a function of φ. (Notice that when r is very small, φ≪1 so that I(r)∝ φ² is very small; then as r increases I(r) increases, overshooting eventually the full–open value.) In our simple formula the first extremum occurs when the sine–function is extremal. In particular, if one “naively” asks for the first maximum we set

  sin²(φ/2) =1  ⟹ φ/2=π/2 ⟹ φ=π.
But φ=π means that
  πr_a²/(λL)=π ⟹ r_a²= λL ⟹ 
  (4)  r_a = √(λL).

–––––––––––––––––––
Part (b). First minimum

In exactly the same way the first (nonzero) minimum occurs when sin²(φ/2) vanishes for the first time after r=0. That is, when

  φ/2 = π  ⟹ φ = 2π.
Then
  πr_b²/(λL)=2π ⟹ r_b²= 2λL ⟹ 
  (5)  r_b = √(2λL).

–––––––––––––––––––
Part (c). Ratio of the intensity for r = r_a to that for r very large

Using Eq. (3) we have
  I(r) ∝4 sin²[φ(r)/2].
When the hole is “full” (r→∞) the integration (or equivalently the Cornu spiral) shows that the transmitted amplitude becomes that of the incident plane wave. (One may show by a more careful treatment that one must “normalize” so that I(∞)=1.) On the other hand, at r=r_a we have found φ = π so that
  I(r_a) ∝4 sin²(π/2)=4.
After normalizing (i.e. dividing by the full–open intensity) the ratio is then

  (6)  I(r_a)/I(∞)= 4.

–––––––––––––––––––
Part (d). Opaque disk of radius r = r_a

Now suppose instead of a circular hole we block a circular disk of radius rₐ in an otherwise completely transmitting screen. By Babinet’s principle the diffraction pattern from an opaque obstacle is the “complement” of that from a hole. (It is a well–known “curiosity” that a circular disk – no matter how big – produces on axis the so–called “Poisson spot” which has the same brightness as the unobstructed beam.) In our simple phase–integral treatment the obstruction produces a complex amplitude which is exactly that “missing” in (1). In other words, if the full wave–front would give a (normalized) amplitude 1 then the amplitude transmitted by the disk is

  U_disk = 1 – U_hole.
But we found U_hole ∝ 1 – e^(i φ) so that at r=r_a (where φ=π) one obtains
  U_disk = 1 – [1 – e^(iπ)] = e^(iπ) = –1.
(In other words, although the phase is reversed the intensity is |–1|²=1.) Thus

  (7)  I_disk = 1,
i.e. the on–axis intensity is the same as for the unobstructed wave.

–––––––––––––––––––
Discussion and Final Answer

One acceptable answer is therefore:

(a) The first maximum (the “overshoot”) occurs when
  πr_a²/(λL)=π  ⟹ r_a = √(λL).

(b) The first minimum (after the overshoot) occurs when
  πr_b²/(λL)=2π  ⟹ r_b = √(2λL).

(c) At r=r_a the light “overshoots” so much that the on–axis intensity (after proper normalization) is four times the fully–open intensity, i.e.
  I(r_a)/I(∞)=4.

(d) By Babinet’s principle if one instead blocks a circular disk of radius r_a the on–axis amplitude is the complementary one. In fact one finds that the Poisson spot has the same brightness as the unobstructed wave:
  I_disk = I(∞)=1.

Any answer equivalent to the one given below is correct.

–––––––––––––––––––
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
(a)\quad & r_a=\sqrt{\lambda L},\\[1mm]
(b)\quad & r_b=\sqrt{2\lambda L},\\[1mm]
(c)\quad & \frac{I(r_a)}{I(\infty)}=4,\\[1mm]
(d)\quad & I_{\text{opaque disk}}=1.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Any answer which shows that the first “overshoot” occurs when πr²/(λL)=π (so that rₐ=√(λL)), the first minimum when πr²/(λL)=2π (so that r_b=√(2λL)), that the on–axis intensity for the hole is 4 times the full–open value when r=rₐ, and that by Babinet’s principle an opaque disk of radius rₐ produces the Poisson spot (with full intensity) is correct.

────────────────────────────
Note:
Some care is needed with overall normalizations. In a rigorous Fresnel–Kirchhoff formulation the on–axis amplitude from a circular aperture is written in terms of the Cornu integrals. (There is a well–known “oscillation” of the on–axis intensity as the aperture is “opened”.) The answers given above – which follow from the simple (but equivalent) expression 
  U ∝ 1 – e^(iπr²/(λL))
– are entirely equivalent to answers expressed in terms of the Cornu integrals.

We are given an object 5 mm long at a distance u = 50 cm = 500 mm from a camera lens. When the film is exactly at the proper image distance the image is 1 mm long. Then the film plate is moved back by 1 cm = 10 mm and a point (or in our case, the “width” of a line‐image) is blurred to 1 mm diameter. We wish to determine the F–number of the lens (often written f/N).

Step 1. Find the magnification and determine the focus image distance.

The magnification m is given by

  m = (image size)/(object size) = 1 mm/5 mm = 0.2.

For a thin lens in focus the magnification is

  m = v/u     (1)

so the image distance is

  v = m·u = 0.2 × 500 mm = 100 mm.

Step 2. Determine the focal length.

The lens equation is

  1/u + 1/v = 1/f.

Substitute u = 500 mm and v = 100 mm:

  1/500 + 1/100 = 1/f   →  0.002 + 0.010 = 0.012 = 1/f,
  thus  f = 1/0.012 ≈ 83.33 mm.

Step 3. Find the relationship between the defocus and the resulting blur circle.

When the film is at the proper location (v = 100 mm), every point is imaged sharply. Now suppose the film is moved back by an amount δ = 10 mm, so the film is at v' = 100 mm + 10 mm = 110 mm. Consider a point object; its rays would converge to a point at z = v if the film were there. But with the film at z = v + δ, the rays, coming from the edge of the aperture (of diameter D = f/N), form a cone that has not come to a complete focus. A simple geometric analysis (see the diagram below) shows that the diameter of the blur circle c is proportional to the extra distance δ and the size of the aperture:

  c = (δ/v) · D.

(Here we use the fact that, over the defocus distance, the cone’s diameter grows linearly; for small defocus errors, the relation is a good approximation.)

Substitute D = f/N:

  c = (δ/v) · (f/N).

We are told that when the film is moved 10 mm behind the focus position, the blurred “width” is c = 1 mm. Therefore,

  1 mm = (10 mm/100 mm) · (f/N).

Simplify:

  1 = (0.1) (f/N)   →  f/N = 1/0.1 = 10.

Step 4. Now substitute for f:

We have already found f ≈ 83.33 mm. Thus

  83.33 mm/N = 10   →  N = 83.33/10 ≈ 8.33.

So the F–number of the lens is approximately 8.33.

Final Answer in Boxed Form:

\[
\boxed{f/8.33}
\]

We start by noting that a fluid in equilibrium under rotation will have a free surface such that the pressure is constant along it. In a rotating frame, the effective potential energy per unit mass at a point (r, z) is given by the sum of gravitational potential and the centrifugal potential:

  V(r, z) = gz – (1/2) ω² r²

Since the free surface is an equipotential surface, we set V(r, z) constant. Let this constant be C. Thus,

  gz – (1/2) ω² r² = C

It is convenient to choose the vertical coordinate such that at the center of rotation (r = 0) the free surface is z = 0. Then at r = 0, we have

  g(0) – (1/2) ω² (0)² = C  ⟹  C = 0

So the equation simplifies to:

  gz = (1/2) ω² r²

or

  z = (ω²/(2g)) r²

This is the equation of a paraboloid.

Now for part (b), we compare the equation of a paraboloid in the form used for telescope mirrors. A parabolic mirror with focal length f is given by

  z = r²/(4f)

Comparing coefficients with the derived equation of the reflecting surface, we set:

  ω²/(2g) = 1/(4f)

Solving for ω²:

  ω² = (2g)/(4f) = g/(2f)

Thus, the angular velocity is given by

  ω = √(g/(2f))

Substituting g = 9.8 m/s² and f = 10 cm = 0.1 m,

  ω = √(9.8/(2 × 0.1)) = √(9.8/0.2) = √(49) = 7 rad/s

So the disk must be rotated at about 7 radians per second.

Final answers:

(a) The free surface is given by  z = (ω²/(2g)) r²

(b) For a 10 cm focal length mirror,  ω = √(g/(2×0.1)) = 7 rad/s

\[ \boxed{\text{(a) } z = \frac{\omega^2}{2g} r^2, \quad \text{(b) } \omega = 7 \, \text{rad/s}} \]

We wish to send a laser beam to the moon with an extremely small divergence – that is, with a diffraction‐limited angular width (measured from the first minimum on one side to the first minimum on the other) of 10⁻⁶ radians. One way to do this is to “expand” the beam using a telescope. The idea is to use a short–focal–length lens to produce a small beam waist that is then “blown up” by a large telescope objective (or mirror) so that the beam fills the telescope’s aperture. The output beam will then be (nearly) collimated, and its angular divergence will be dominated by diffraction through the (now large) aperture. For a diffraction–limited beam the smallest achievable divergence is roughly determined by the size of the aperture.

Let’s now go step by step:

1. Diffraction Limit for a Rectangular Aperture

If we suppose that the telescope’s objective has a rectangular aperture of width a, then the familiar single–slit (or rectangular aperture) diffraction formula tells us that the first minimum occurs when
  sinθ ≈ θ ≈ λ/a   (for small angles). 
Since the pattern is symmetric the first minimum on one side is at about +θ and on the other side at −θ. Thus the full angular width (from first minimum to first minimum) is approximately 
  Δθ ≈ 2λ/a.

We want Δθ to be 10⁻⁶ rad. Thus we set
  2λ/a = 10⁻⁶  ⇒  a = 2λ/10⁻⁶.

2. Numerical Example

For a visible laser we could take, for example, λ = 500×10⁻⁹ m (500 nm). Then
  a = (2 × 500×10⁻⁹ m) / 10⁻⁶ = (1000×10⁻⁹) / 10⁻⁶ = 1.0 m.

Thus the objective (or mirror) of the telescope should have an aperture of about 1 meter (in the dimension that determines the diffraction) so that the beam after expansion is diffraction–limited to a full angular width of about 10⁻⁶ radians.

3. Role of the Short–Focus Lens

The laser itself typically produces a beam that is narrow but of modest diameter. To take full advantage of a 1–meter telescope, you need to “fill” its aperture with light. A short–focal–length lens is used to focus the laser beam down to a small waist. By then placing the telescope objective (or using the telescope in reverse) so that the small waist is located in its focal plane, you obtain a collimated beam whose diameter is essentially the size of the telescope’s aperture. In other words, the short–focus lens has to be chosen (with a correspondingly large numerical aperture) so that the laser beam is expanded to the size needed to uniformly illuminate the telescope aperture.

4. Summary of the Required Characteristics

• Telescope (or mirror) objective:
  – Must be diffraction–limited.
  – Must have an effective aperture (in the “width” direction) of order 1 m (for a 500 nm laser) so that
   2λ / a ≈ 10⁻⁶ rad.
  (For a circular aperture one would use the similar Rayleigh criterion, 1.22λ/D ≈ 10⁻⁶ rad, which for 500 nm gives D ≈ 0.61 m. The rectangular case gives a comparable answer when taking into account exactly how the “angular width” is defined.)

• Short–focus lens:
  – Must have a short enough focal length and a sufficiently large clear aperture such that the laser beam is focused to a small waist
  – The telescope is then used (in “reverse”) to take this waist and produce a nearly collimated beam that fills a 1–m aperture, hence achieving a divergence set by the diffraction limit.

Thus, by using a carefully chosen short–focal–length lens to prepare the beam and a high–quality, large (≈1 m) aperture telescope objective to expand it, you obtain a beam whose full diffraction pattern (first minimum to first minimum) is about 10⁻⁶ radians. This is critical when trying to send a beam to a distant target like the moon so as to minimize spreading.

Thus, the telescope objective must be diffraction–limited over an aperture of roughly 1 m, and the short–focal–length lens must be chosen to produce a small beam waist that fills this aperture.}} \]

We start from the grating equation for transmission gratings at normal incidence:

  d sin θ = mλ

where
  d = grating spacing,
  θ = diffraction angle,
  m = diffraction order (an integer: ±0, ±1, ±2, …),
  λ = wavelength of light.

Step 1. Find d (the spacing between adjacent lines).  
The grating has 250 lines per mm, so
  d = 1 mm / 250 = (1 × 10⁻³ m) / 250 = 4 × 10⁻⁶ m.

Step 2. Write the equation at θ = 30°  
We have sin 30° = 1/2, so:
  4 × 10⁻⁶ m × (1/2) = mλ  ⟹  λ = (2 × 10⁻⁶ m) / m

Step 3. Determine which orders give wavelengths in the visible region (~400 nm to 700 nm).  
For m = 1, 2, …:
 • m = 1: λ = 2×10⁻⁶ m = 2000 nm (infrared)  
 • m = 2: λ = 1×10⁻⁶ m = 1000 nm (infrared)  
 • m = 3: λ = (2×10⁻⁶)/3 ≈ 6.67×10⁻⁷ m = 667 nm  [red region]  
 • m = 4: λ = (2×10⁻⁶)/4 = 5.00×10⁻⁷ m = 500 nm  [green region]  
 • m = 5: λ = (2×10⁻⁶)/5 = 4.00×10⁻⁷ m = 400 nm  [violet region]  
 • m = 6: λ ≈ 333 nm (ultraviolet)

Only m = 3, 4, and 5 fall in the visible range.

Step 4. Identify the colors.  
• λ ≈ 667 nm is in the red portion of the spectrum.  
• λ ≈ 500 nm falls in the green region.  
• λ ≈ 400 nm is in the violet part of the spectrum.

Thus, at a diffraction angle of 30°, the wavelengths observed (in the ± orders) in the visible region are approximately 667 nm, 500 nm, and 400 nm corresponding to red, green, and violet light respectively.

We wish to find the angular intensity pattern produced by a diffraction grating with N equally spaced “slits” (lines) separated by a distance d when illuminated by monochromatic light of wavelength λ at normal incidence. (We ignore the finite slit width so that only the interference of the light from different slits matters.) In addition, we will use this result together with the Rayleigh criterion to show that in diffraction order m the grating can resolve two wavelengths provided

  (Δλ/λ) = 1/(mN).

Below we describe step by step the derivations.

────────────────────────────
Step (a): Intensity Distribution

1. Each of the N slits is illuminated coherently and so we may represent its electric field contribution as having equal amplitude and a phase which depends on the extra path length to a point P on the screen at an angle θ relative to the normal.

2. The extra path from one slit relative to the next is
  Δ = d sin θ.
Hence the phase difference between light from successive slits is

  δ = kΔ = (2π/λ) d sin θ.

3. The net field is the sum of N contributions whose phases form an arithmetic progression:
  E(θ) = E₀ [1 + e^(iδ) + e^(i2δ) + ⋯ + e^(i(N–1)δ)],
where E₀ is the field from one slit. This is a geometric series with N terms.

4. Summing the series (recall that for a geometric series, 1+z+z²+…+z^(N–1) = (1–z^(N))/(1–z) for z ≠ 1) we find
  E(θ) = E₀ (1 – e^(iNδ))/(1 – e^(iδ)).
A little algebra (multiplying numerator and denominator by e^(–iNδ/2) and e^(–iδ/2) respectively) yields
  E(θ) = E₀ e^(i(N–1)δ/2) [sin(Nδ/2) / sin(δ/2)].

5. The intensity is proportional to the square modulus of the field. Since the overall phase factor has no effect on the intensity,
  I(θ) ∝ |E(θ)|² = I₀ [sin(Nδ/2) / sin(δ/2)]²,
with I₀ (the single-slit intensity) setting the overall constant.

6. Writing the answer explicitly in terms of the parameters we defined,
  δ = (2π/λ)d sinθ,
so that the final angular intensity distribution is

  I(θ) = I(0) [sin((Nπd sinθ)/λ) / sin((πd sinθ)/λ)]².

────────────────────────────
Step (b): Resolving Power Using the Rayleigh Criterion

1. The condition for the principal (central) maximum in interference is that the contributions from all slits add in phase. This gives the grating equation:
  d sinθ = mλ    for m = 0, ±1, ±2, … 
where m is the order of the diffraction maximum.

2. Now consider two close wavelengths λ and λ + Δλ that both satisfy the grating equation nearly at the same angle. Their maxima occur at slightly different angles. For the two wavelengths to be just resolved according to the Rayleigh criterion, the principal maximum of one wavelength must coincide with the first minimum of the other.

3. We know from the form of the intensity envelope of an N-slit grating that the angular width (the angular separation between the central maximum and the first minimum) is given by the condition that the numerator sin(Nδ/2) first goes to zero (apart from the trivial solution δ = 0). That is, the first minimum occurs when

  Nδ/2 = π  ⟹  δ = (2π/N).

But recall δ is given by
  δ = (2π/λ)d sinθ,
so in the vicinity of the mth maximum (where d sinθ = mλ) a small change Δλ will shift δ by
  Δδ = (2πd sinθ/λ²) Δλ.
At the maximum, d sinθ = mλ, hence
  Δδ = (2πmλ/λ²) Δλ = (2πm/λ) Δλ.

4. Equate the shift in δ to the angular width of the principal maximum (in phase):
  (2π m/λ) Δλ = 2π/N.
Canceling 2π from both sides gives
  m(Δλ/λ) = 1/N ⟹  Δλ/λ = 1/(mN).

5. Thus the resolving power R (which is the reciprocal of Δλ/λ) is

  R = λ/Δλ = mN.

────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The intensity distribution as a function of angle is

  I(θ) = I(0) [ sin((Nπd sinθ)/λ) / sin((πd sinθ)/λ) ]².

(b) The resolving power in order m is given by

  Δλ/λ = 1/(mN),  or equivalently,  R = mN.

────────────────────────────

Step 1. Identify the relevant formula

The resolution of a telescope is limited by diffraction, which is given by the Rayleigh criterion. The angular resolution (in radians) is approximately

  θ = 1.22 (λ/D),

where
  λ is the wavelength of light and
  D is the diameter of the objective.

Step 2. Convert the given wavelength

The wavelength is given as 6000 Å. Recall that

  1 Å = 10⁻⁸ cm  or  1 Å = 10⁻¹⁰ m.

Thus,

  λ = 6000 Å = 6000 × 10⁻¹⁰ m = 6 × 10⁻⁷ m.

Step 3. Use the objective’s diameter

The telescope’s objective diameter is given as 8 cm. Converting centimeters to meters,

  D = 8 cm = 0.08 m.

Step 4. Calculate the angular resolution (in radians)

Plugging into the formula,

  θ = 1.22 × (6 × 10⁻⁷ m) / (0.08 m)
    = (1.22 × 6 × 10⁻⁷)/0.08.

Calculate the numerator first:

  1.22 × 6 × 10⁻⁷ = 7.32 × 10⁻⁷.

Then,

  θ = 7.32 × 10⁻⁷ / 0.08 ≈ 9.15 × 10⁻⁶ radians.

Step 5. Convert radians to arc seconds

There are 206265 arc seconds in a radian. Thus,

  θ (in arc sec) = 9.15 × 10⁻⁶ radians × 206265 arc sec/radian.

Multiplying out,

  θ ≈ 1.888 arc sec ≈ 1.9 arc sec.

We can estimate the distance at which two point sources (the car headlights) can be just resolved using the Rayleigh criterion for a circular aperture, which tells us that the minimum angular separation (θ_min) that can be resolved is given by

  θ_min ≈ 1.22 (λ / D)

where
 • λ is the wavelength of light (in meters),
 • D is the diameter of the pupil (in meters).

For two objects separated by a distance d at a distance L, the angular separation is approximately

  θ = d / L.

The headlights are just resolved when

  d / L = 1.22 (λ / D).

Solving for L gives

  L = (d D) / (1.22 λ).

Now, we substitute in the given values:
 • d = 1.3 m,
 • D = 4 mm = 0.004 m,
 • λ = 5500 Å = 5500 × 10⁻¹⁰ m = 550 × 10⁻⁹ m.

Thus,

  L = (1.3 m × 0.004 m) / (1.22 × 550 × 10⁻⁹ m).

First, compute the numerator:
  1.3 × 0.004 = 0.0052 m².

Then, compute the denominator:
  1.22 × 550 × 10⁻⁹ = 671 × 10⁻⁹ = 6.71 × 10⁻⁷ m.

So,

  L = 0.0052 m² / (6.71 × 10⁻⁷ m) ≈ 7740 m.

This distance is approximately 7.7 kilometers.

Therefore, the headlights can just be resolved at a distance of approximately

  \[\boxed{7.7\times 10^3\, \text{m}}\]

Below is one way to “measure the wavelength with a ruler” – by using a diffraction‐interference pattern produced by the laser. (Note that there are several “do‐it‐at‐home” versions of this experiment; here we describe one typical procedure.) 

──────────────────────────────
1. The Idea of the Experiment

A laser beam is sent through an optical element that “splits” it (for example, a double‐slit or a diffraction grating). As a result, you see on a screen a pattern consisting of a bright central maximum and a series of secondary (or “order‐m”) maxima on either side. Since all the light comes from one coherent source, the interference of the different “parts” of the beam produces these fringes. Although the optical element is micro‐structured, its periodic spacing is provided by the apparatus (often printed in a small label or given in the lab instructions).

For instance, when a beam is diffracted by a grating whose “line‐spacing” is d, the grating equation tells us that the angles θ at which we see bright “orders” satisfy

  d sinθ = m λ        (1)

with m = 0, ±1, ±2, ….

──────────────────────────────
2. What You Measure Directly

(a) You measure (with your meter‐stick or ruler) the distance L from the grating (or slit) to the screen.  
(b) You “read off” the positions of the bright spots on the screen. In particular, you determine the distance y from the central (m = 0) maximum to the mth order maximum (often the first order is the easiest to measure accurately).  
(c) (Often the grating “constant” d is given by the experimenter.)

Under the (“small‐angle”) condition – often valid if L is much larger than the fringe spacing – we have

  sinθ ≈ tanθ ≈ y / L    (2)

──────────────────────────────
3. Relating Observations to the Wavelength

Insert (2) into (1) (choosing, say, m = 1): 

  d (y/L) = λ   →  λ = d (y / L).   (3)

Thus if you know d and you measure y and L, you can “calculate” the wavelength of the light.

──────────────────────────────
4. A Sample Calculation

Suppose that by looking at the pattern you determine the following:

• The distance between the grating (or slit) and the screen is 
  L = 2.00 m.

• The distance from the central (m = 0) maximum to the first-order (m = 1) maximum is measured to be 
  y = 5.06 mm = 5.06 × 10⁻³ m.

• (For example, the apparatus might have a double-slit whose slit–center separation is given to be 
  d = 0.250 mm = 2.50 × 10⁻⁴ m.)

Then, using (3) with m = 1,
  λ = d (y / L) = (2.50×10⁻⁴ m) × (5.06×10⁻³ m / 2.00 m).

Let’s compute the numbers:
  (5.06×10⁻³ m / 2.00 m) = 2.53×10⁻³,
so
  λ = (2.50×10⁻⁴ m) × (2.53×10⁻³) ≈ 6.33×10⁻⁷ m.

That result is approximately 633 nm, which is a typical wavelength for a red He–Ne laser.

──────────────────────────────
5. Final Answer

Based on the measurement procedure and using the interference–diffraction formula, one finds that

  λ ≈ 6.33×10⁻⁷ m   (or approximately 633 nm).

This shows how, with only a ruler (and the provided grating or slit geometry) you can “measure” the wavelength of a laser.
 
──────────────────────────────

\]

Step 1. Determine the focal length.
For a spherical mirror, the focal length f is half the radius of curvature R. Here, R = 12 inches, so

  f = R/2 = 12/2 = 6 inches.

Step 2. Use the mirror equation.
The mirror equation is given by

  1/f = 1/d_o + 1/d_i,

where
  d_o = object distance (4 inches),
  d_i = image distance (unknown).

Substitute the values:

  1/6 = 1/4 + 1/d_i.

Step 3. Solve for the image distance d_i.
Rearrange the equation to isolate 1/d_i:

  1/d_i = 1/6 − 1/4.

Compute the difference by finding a common denominator (12):

  1/6 = 2/12  and  1/4 = 3/12,
  1/d_i = (2/12 − 3/12) = −1/12.

Thus, 

  d_i = −12 inches.

The negative sign indicates that the image is virtual (it forms on the same side as the object).

Step 4. Determine the magnification.
The magnification m is given by

  m = − (d_i / d_o).

Substituting the known values:

  m = − (−12 / 4) = 12/4 = 3.

This positive magnification tells us that the image is upright and three times larger than the object.

Step 5. Ray Diagram Description.
Here is a step-by-step verbal description of the ray diagram for clarity:

1. Draw the principal axis (a horizontal line) and mark the mirror’s vertex (V). The mirror is concave (curved inward).
2. Mark the focal point (F) at 6 inches from the vertex and the center of curvature (C) at 12 inches.
3. Place the object (representing a face) at 4 inches from V along the principal axis.
4. Draw the following rays from the top of the object:
  a. A ray parallel to the principal axis. After hitting the mirror, it seems to diverge from the focal point behind the mirror.
  b. A ray directed toward the center of curvature (C); it will reflect back on itself.
  c. A ray that goes through the focal point (F) if extended backwards; upon reflection, it leaves parallel to the principal axis.
5. Extend the reflected rays backward. The point where they appear to diverge from (behind the mirror) is the location of the virtual image. Since the reflected rays do not actually meet, the image is virtual.
6. The spacing in the diagram shows that the virtual image is located 12 inches behind the mirror (from the vertex) and is three times the size of the object.

We are given an object of height h located 40 cm to the left of a converging lens (Lens 1) with focal length f₁ = 10 cm. A second converging lens (Lens 2) with focal length f₂ = 20 cm is located 30 cm to the right of Lens 1. (See the rough sketch below for the geometry, where we define a coordinate system with Lens 1 at x = 0 and the positive x‐axis directed to the right.)

Step 1. (Image formed by Lens 1)

The object is at a distance dₒ₁ = 40 cm (to the left of Lens 1).

Using the thin lens formula for Lens 1:
  1/f₁ = 1/dₒ₁ + 1/dᵢ₁,
we have

  1/10 = 1/40 + 1/dᵢ₁   ⇒ 1/dᵢ₁ = 1/10 – 1/40.
Writing the fractions with a common denominator:
  1/10 = 4/40  so  1/dᵢ₁ = (4/40 – 1/40) = 3/40.
Thus,
  dᵢ₁ = 40/3 ≈ 13.33 cm.

This means the image formed by Lens 1 is 13.33 cm to the right of Lens 1.

The lateral magnification of Lens 1 is given by
  m₁ = – dᵢ₁/dₒ₁ = – (40/3)/40 = – 1/3.
So the image has a height h₁ = m₁·h = –h/3 (the minus sign indicates the image is inverted relative to the object).

Step 2. (Image formed by Lens 2)

Lens 2 is 30 cm to the right of Lens 1. The image from Lens 1 serves as the object for Lens 2. Its location is x = +13.33 cm (relative to Lens 1), so the distance from Lens 2 is:

  dₒ₂ = (distance between Lens 2 and image) = 30 cm – 13.33 cm = 16.67 cm.
In exact form, note that
  dₒ₂ = 30 – (40/3) = (90 – 40)/3 = 50/3 cm.

For Lens 2 we have f₂ = 20 cm. Apply the thin lens formula:
  1/f₂ = 1/dₒ₂ + 1/dᵢ₂,
so
  1/20 = 1/(50/3) + 1/dᵢ₂.
Since 1/(50/3) = 3/50, we write:
  1/dᵢ₂ = 1/20 – 3/50.
Write these fractions with a common denominator:
  1/20 = 5/100  and  3/50 = 6/100.
Thus,
  1/dᵢ₂ = (5/100 – 6/100) = –1/100.
So,
  dᵢ₂ = –100 cm.
The negative sign (with the convention that distances measured to the right of the lens are positive) tells us that the final image is virtual and appears 100 cm to the left of Lens 2.

The magnification for Lens 2 is:
  m₂ = – dᵢ₂/dₒ₂ = – (–100)/(50/3) = 100/(50/3) = 100·3/50 = 6.

Step 3. (Overall Magnification and Final Image Height)

The overall magnification is the product:

Thus, the final image has height

The negative sign indicates that the final image is inverted relative to the original.

We will show that by a careful application of the Fresnel–Kirchhoff diffraction integral (or, equivalently, by using Babinet’s principle) one may prove that if a plane‐wave of intensity

  I₀

is incident normally on an obstacle, then the intensity on the axis (at a distance L behind the obstacle, with L ≫ R) is as follows:

(a) For an opaque circular disk (the “Arago spot” case),
  I₍disk₎(0) = I₀.

(b) For an opaque screen with a circular hole of radius R,
  I₍hole₎(0) = 4 I₀ sin²( (πR²)/(2λL) )
which, when (πR²)/(2λL) is small (as it typically is when L ≫ R) may be approximated by
  I₍hole₎(0) ≈ I₀ (πR²/(λL))².

Below we describe one way to arrive at these answers.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. The Diffraction Integral

For propagation in the Fresnel (or Fraunhofer) limit the complex amplitude at a point P a distance L away from an aperture is given by

  U(P) = (exp(ikL)/(iλL)) ∫_aperture U₀ exp[ik (x′²+y′²)/(2L)] dS′,
        (1)

where k = 2π/λ, U₀ is the amplitude of the incident plane wave (with I₀ ∝ |U₀|²), and the integration extends over the open part of the screen.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. The Case of a Circular Aperture (Hole)

When the screen has a circular hole of radius R the integration is over the disk r ≤ R. In polar coordinates (with constant phase factor coming from a quadratic phase term) we have

  U₍hole₎(0) = (exp(ikL)/(iλL)) 2π ∫₀ᴿ r exp[ik r²/(2L)] dr.
        (2)

Make the substitution u = (k r²)/(2L) so that
  du = (k/L) r dr  ⇒  r dr = (L/k) du.
When r = R, u = (kR²)/(2L). Then (2) becomes

  U₍hole₎(0) = (exp(ikL)/(iλL)) 2π (L/k) ∫₀^(kR²/(2L)) exp(iu) du.
        (3)

But note that k = 2π/λ so that

  2π (L/k) = 2π L/(2π/λ) = λL.
Thus, one finds

  U₍hole₎(0) = (exp(ikL)/(iλL)) (λL) [exp(iu) – 1] evaluated between 0 and (kR²)/(2L),
i.e.,

  U₍hole₎(0) = U₀ exp(ikL) [1 – exp(iΦ)],
       (4)

where

  Φ = (kR²)/(2L) = (2π/λ)(R²/(2L)) = (πR²)/(λL).

Thus the intensity on the axis (due solely to light passing through the hole) is

  I₍hole₎(0) = I₀ |1 – exp(iΦ)|² = 4 I₀ sin²(Φ/2).
In other words,
  I₍hole₎(0) = 4 I₀ sin²((πR²)/(2λL)).  (5)

Note that for (πR²)/(2λL) ≪ 1 one may use sin x ≈ x so that

  I₍hole₎(0) ≈ 4 I₀ ( (πR²)/(2λL) )² = I₀ (πR²/(λL))².  (6)

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. The Case of an Opaque Disk

Babinet’s principle tells us that the sum of the fields produced by two complementary screens (one having an aperture where the other has an obstruction) is equal to the field in the absence of any obstacle. That is, if U₍disk₎(0) is the field on axis when there is an opaque disk and U₍hole₎(0) is that due to the complementary circular aperture (hole), then

  U₍disk₎(0) + U₍hole₎(0) = U_free(0) = U₀ exp(ikL).
Thus, using (4) for U₍hole₎(0) one finds

  U₍disk₎(0) = U₀ exp(ikL) – U₍hole₎(0)
        = U₀ exp(ikL) – U₀ exp(ikL)[1 – exp(iΦ)]
        = U₀ exp(ikL) exp(iΦ).
Since a phase factor does not change the intensity, we have

  I₍disk₎(0) = I₀.  (7)

This is the famous Arago spot: although a large opaque disk blocks a central part of the incoming wave, diffraction from its edge interferes constructively on axis so that the intensity there is the same as that of the unobstructed beam.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

Thus, we may state that for L ≫ R:

(a) With an opaque circular disk of radius R the intensity on axis is

  I₍disk₎(0) = I₀.

(b) With an opaque screen having a circular hole of radius R the on‐axis intensity is

  I₍hole₎(0) = 4 I₀ sin²((πR²)/(2λL))
       ≈ I₀ (πR²/(λL))²    (for (πR²)/(2λL) ≪ 1).

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Box

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad I_{\text{disk}}(0) &= I_0,\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad I_{\text{hole}}(0) &= 4 I_0\, \sin^2\!\Bigl(\frac{\pi R^2}{2\lambda L}\Bigr)
\approx I_0\left(\frac{\pi R^2}{\lambda L}\right)^2 \quad \text{(if }\pi R^2/(2\lambda L)\ll 1\text{).}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

To estimate the smallest crater diameter that a telescope can discern, we first need to find the angular resolution limited by diffraction. For a simple approximation using the single-slit (or circular aperture) model, the diffraction angle is given by

  θ ≈ λ / D,

where λ is the wavelength of light and D is the diameter of the objective lens.

Step 1. Substitute the given values:
  λ = 5 × 10^(-7) m,
  D = 1/2 m = 0.5 m.

Thus,
  θ ≈ (5 × 10^(-7) m) / (0.5 m) = 1 × 10^(-6) radians.

Step 2. The smallest discernible detail on the Moon (i.e., the crater diameter) can be estimated by multiplying this angular resolution by the distance to the Moon, L:

  Δx ≈ θ × L,

with L given as 3.8 × 10^8 m.

So, we have:
  Δx ≈ 1 × 10^(-6) rad × 3.8 × 10^8 m = 380 m.

Thus, the telescope can resolve craters on the Moon that are about 380 meters in diameter or larger.

Step 1. Determine the aperture diameter.

The f-number (f/#) is given by
  f/# = focal length / aperture diameter.
Given a 50 mm focal length and f/2, the diameter D is
  D = 50 mm / 2 = 25 mm = 0.025 m.

Step 2. Use the Rayleigh criterion to find the smallest resolvable angular separation.

According to the Rayleigh criterion, the minimum angular resolution (in radians) is approximately:
  θ ≈ 1.22 λ / D,
where λ is a typical wavelength of visible light. For our estimation, assume λ ≈ 500 nm = 500×10⁻⁹ m.

Thus,
  θ ≈ (1.22 × 500×10⁻⁹ m) / 0.025 m
  θ ≈ (610×10⁻⁹) / 0.025
  θ ≈ 2.44×10⁻⁵ radians (or about 24.4 microradians).

Step 3. Translate this angular resolution to a linear distance at 100 km.

The smallest resolvable feature size (s) at a distance L is approximately:
  s = L × θ.
Here, L = 100 km = 100,000 m, so:
  s = 100,000 m × 2.44×10⁻⁵
  s ≈ 2.44 m.

Step 4. Compare this to the separation between the two car headlights.

Typical headlight separations on a car are on the order of 1–2 m. Since our calculated smallest resolvable separation is about 2.44 m, the two headlights would be close to, or below, the diffraction limit of the lens system.

Step 5. Final evaluation.

Given the diffraction limit imposed by a 25 mm aperture at visible wavelengths, the camera would only be able to distinguish two points on Earth if they are more than roughly 2.44 m apart. With car headlights typically separated by about 1–2 m, you cannot expect to fully resolve them as individual sources in the image.

Thus, the final answer is:

\[
\boxed{\text{No, the optics would not have sufficient resolution at 100 km to resolve the two headlights.}}

We wish to study the interference pattern produced by a grating in which the individual rulings (or slits) have negligible width. In effect, each ruling acts like a point source so that the pattern is due solely to the interference of light from many equally spaced sources.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Intensity Distribution

Let there be N rulings (sources) placed along a line with equal spacing d (the grating constant). When a plane wave of monochromatic light of wavelength λ is incident on the grating, the light emerging from the different rulings acquires a phase difference due to the different optical paths. If we choose an angle θ from the normal, the extra path difference from one ruling to the next is
  Δ = d sin θ.
Thus the phase difference between light from successive rulings is 
  φ = (2π/λ)(d sin θ).

Since the rulings are assumed to be “infinitely narrow” (i.e. their own diffraction is not considered) the amplitude from each ruling may be taken as A (assumed equal for all).

The complex amplitude at an angle θ is then given by the sum of the contributions from all rulings:
  E(θ) = A + Ae^(iφ) + Ae^(i2φ) + … + Ae^(i(N–1)φ).

This geometric series can be summed to give
  E(θ) = A exp[i(N–1)φ/2] · [sin(Nφ/2)/sin(φ/2)]
where we have used the standard formula for the sum of a finite geometric series. (The phase factor exp[i(N–1)φ/2] is unimportant when calculating the intensity.)

Thus, the intensity, which is proportional to the square of the modulus of the amplitude, is
  I(θ) = I₀ |E(θ)/A|² = I₀ [sin(Nφ/2)/sin(φ/2)]²
with
  φ = (2π/λ) d sin θ.
This is the well-known interference formula for a grating with N sources, showing very sharp principal (or “principal”) maxima when the argument of the numerator is an integer multiple of π.

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Number of Subsidiary Maxima

The principal maxima occur when the phasors all add in phase. That is, when the phase difference is a multiple of 2π:
  φ = (2π/λ) d sin θ = 2πm  , m = 0, ±1, ±2, … 
which gives the condition:
  d sin θ = mλ.
At these angles the numerator is sin(Nπm) = 0 except that the denominator is also zero; however the limit is finite and these become the principal (very sharp) peaks.

In between these principal maxima the function 
  f(θ) = [sin(Nφ/2)/sin(φ/2)]²
has other local maxima (and minima). A standard result from interference theory (which you may derive by setting the derivative with respect to θ equal to zero, or by considering the structure of the function) is that there are exactly (N – 2) subsidiary (i.e. less intense) maxima between two successive principal maxima. 

For example, if N = 2 (a double‐slit) there are no subsidiary maxima; if N = 3 there is one; if N = 4 there are two; and so on.

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): Are the Intensities of the Subsidiary Maxima Identical?

No, they are not identical. Although the condition for a local maximum is determined by the same function f(θ) = [sin(Nφ/2)/sin(φ/2)]², the positions of these subsidiary maxima are not uniformly spaced in phase, and their heights differ. In fact, it turns out that:
 • The principal maxima (where the phasors are exactly in phase) have the maximum intensity.
 • The subsidiary maxima, which occur at angles where the phasors do not all align perfectly, have intensities that vary with angle and are always lower than the principal peak. 
Thus, the subsidiary maxima do not all have the same intensity.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The intensity distribution is given by

  I(θ) = I₀ [sin(Nπ d sin θ/λ)/ sin(π d sin θ/λ)]².

(b) The number of subsidiary maxima between consecutive principal maxima is (N – 2).

(c) No; the subsidiary maxima have different intensities—they are lower than the principal maxima and their heights vary with the angle.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & I(\theta)=I_0\left[\frac{\sin\left(\frac{N\pi d\sin\theta}{\lambda}\right)}
{\sin\left(\frac{\pi d\sin\theta}{\lambda}\right)}\right]^2,\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & \text{Between two successive principal maxima there are } N-2 \text{ subsidiary maxima},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad & \text{No; the subsidiary maxima are not identical in intensity.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to study the interference produced when a plane wave (wavelength λ) is incident normally on a grating of 6 identical, equally‐spaced slits (separated by spacing d). In what follows we assume that the slit widths are negligible so that only interference (and no diffraction envelope) is considered unless noted otherwise.

Let the number of slits be N = 6. We denote by m an integer (…, –2, –1, 0, 1, 2, …) that labels the interference orders.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Angles for the Interference Maxima

For N equally spaced slits, the path difference between light emerging from adjacent slits is
  δ = d sin θ.
For constructive interference (all waves arriving in phase) the phase difference must be an integer multiple of 2π. In terms of path difference, this is equivalent to
  d sin θ = m λ       (m = 0, ±1, ±2, …)
In other words, the interference maxima occur at angles fulfilling
  sin θ = m λ/d.
Thus, the interference peaks (sometimes called “principal maxima”) occur at those angles.

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Angular Width of the Interference Maxima

The intensity for a grating with N slits is often written in the form

  I(θ) ∝ [sin(Nϕ/2) / sin(ϕ/2)]²,

where the phase increment ϕ is given by
  ϕ = (2π/λ) d sin θ.
At a maximum (say at m, where d sinθ_m = mλ) we have ϕ = 2π m. To find the angular “half‐width” (from the maximum to the nearest zero, or “null”) we look for the first zero of the numerator (other than the trivial zero at ϕ = 0). The first zero away from ϕ = 2π m comes when

  Nϕ/2 = ±π  ⟹  ϕ = ±(2π/N).

Express ϕ in terms of a small deviation Δθ from the mth maximum; writing

  ϕ = (2π/λ)d sin (θ_m + Δθ) ≈ (2π/λ)[d sinθ_m + d cosθ_m Δθ].

Since d sinθ_m = mλ, we have

  ϕ ≈ 2π m + (2π d cosθ_m/λ) Δθ.

We want the deviation from the maximum (where the phase is exactly 2πm) to equal Δϕ = ±(2π/N):

  (2π d cosθ_m/λ) Δθ = ± (2π/N).

Cancel 2π from both sides to obtain

  Δθ = ± λ/(N d cosθ_m).

In many cases (especially for the central maximum where m = 0 and cosθ_0 = 1) this yields

  Δθ = λ/(6 d).

Thus the angular “half‐width” (from the maximum to the first null) is

  Δθ ≈ λ/(N d cosθ_m).

For small angles and the central maximum, cosθ ≈ 1 so that Δθ ≈ λ/(6d).

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): Ratio of Intensity at an Interference Maximum to that from a Single Slit

When the waves from N slits interfere constructively, their amplitudes add. If each slit gives a field amplitude E₀, then at a principal maximum the resulting amplitude is

  E_total = N E₀   (since all are in phase).
The intensity, which is proportional to the square of the amplitude, is

  I_max ∝ |N E₀|² = N² |E₀|².
For a single slit the intensity is (proportional to) |E₀|², so that

  I_max/I_single = N² = 6² = 36.
Thus, the maximum (principal maximum) produced by the grating is 36 times as intense as the light from a single slit.

──────────────────────────────
Step (d): Sketch of the Interference Pattern

It is instructive to describe the qualitative appearance of the interference pattern as a function of angle θ.

1. The principal (bright) maxima occur at angles where d sinθ = m λ. Thus, one would see a central maximum at θ = 0 and symmetric maxima at angles θ given by m = ±1, ±2, …, limited by the requirement |sinθ| ≤ 1.

2. The maxima are very narrow. In fact, their angular half‐width is Δθ ≈ λ/(6d) (for the central maximum). That is, the bright peaks are sharp.

3. In between these bright spots the intensity falls to zero (at the positions of the “nulls” determined by sin(Nϕ/2) = 0 other than at the main maxima).

A schematic diagram would show a sharply peaked central maximum at θ = 0 with equally spaced secondary maxima at angles ±m λ/d. The peaks become vanishingly narrow as one moves away from the center (although in a real experiment the individual slit diffraction envelope may modulate these, here we have assumed negligible slit width).

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The interference maxima occur at angles θ given by:
  d sin θ = m λ  (m = 0, ±1, ±2, …).

(b) The angular half‐width (from the maximum to the nearest null) is approximately:
  Δθ ≈ λ/(N d cosθ)  which, for m = 0 (central maximum), becomes Δθ ≈ λ/(6d).

(c) The interference maximum (with 6 slits) has an intensity 6² = 36 times that from one slit.

(d) The interference pattern, as a function of angle, consists of a central bright (and very narrow) peak at θ = 0 with additional, equally spaced bright peaks at angles satisfying sin θ = mλ/d. Between these peaks the intensity falls to zero.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in Boxed Form

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & d\sin\theta = m\lambda,\quad m=0,\pm1,\pm2,\dots, \\
\text{(b)}\quad & \Delta\theta\approx\frac{\lambda}{N\,d\cos\theta}\quad (\text{so for }m=0,\ \Delta\theta\approx\frac{\lambda}{6d}), \\
\text{(c)}\quad & \frac{I_{\text{max}}}{I_{\text{single}}}=N^2=36, \\
\text{(d)}\quad & \text{A central peak at } \theta=0 \text{ with narrow peaks at } \theta \text{ where } d\sin\theta = m\lambda.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We will show that the radiation produced by a charged particle running parallel to a periodically “structured” surface (a grating) has a frequency that is determined both by the particle’s speed and the time delays between the “events” at successive grooves. In what follows we explain in some detail one acceptable derivation.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. The Basic Idea

When a charged particle of speed v passes by a grating with grooves separated by a distance d, each groove “responds” (by producing a polarized current or dipole moment) when the particle is nearby. One may idealize the situation by saying that the grating produces a series of “pulses” of electromagnetic radiation. Since the particle moves uniformly, successive pulses are produced with a fixed time delay

  Δt_emission = d/v.

However, when an observer at large distance looks at the radiation, the wave from the groove that was “hit” later (with index 2 say) has to travel a different distance than that from the groove hit earlier (index 1). For an observer looking in a direction which makes an angle θ (measured from the particle’s direction, which we will take as the x‑axis) the extra path difference is (approximately) 

  Δℓ = d cos θ
           (when the grooves are arranged along the x‑axis).

Thus the extra propagation delay is

  Δt_propagation = d cos θ / c.

These two time delays combine to give an effective “time shift” between pulses as seen by the observer

  Δt_total = (d/v) − (d cos θ/c).

For constructive interference (or equivalently, to get a strong “order” m) the phase difference between pulses must be an integral multiple of 2π.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. The Phase condition

A pulse radiated at one groove has a phase φ₁ = ω t. At the next groove the emission occurs delayed by d/v but then the extra propagation delay subtracts d cosθ/c. Hence the phase difference between successive contributions is

  Δφ = ω (d/v − d cos θ/c) = 2π m,   m = 1, 2, 3, … .

Thus, the angular frequency of the radiation (in the mth “order”) is given by

  ω = 2π m / [d (1/v – cos θ/c)].

Equivalently, the frequency is

  f = ω/(2π) = m / [d (1/v – cos θ/c)].

Notice that for non‐relativistic particles (v ≪ c) the second term is small and f ≃ m v/d (nearly independent of the observation angle) but when the particle speed is a significant fraction of c the Doppler-like term cosθ/c can greatly change the observed frequency.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Answer to Part (a)

Thus, for a metallic diffraction grating the frequency of the emitted radiation depends on the observation angle θ via

  f(θ) = m / [d (1/v – cos θ/c)]       (for integer m).

In words, as the angle of observation changes (with θ measured relative to the particle’s direction), the effective delay between pulses changes because of the extra path difference, so that the radiation is “dispersed” in frequency according to the above relation.

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Answer to Part (b)

Now, suppose that instead of a metallic grating one has a transmission grating (say, a piece of glass on which grooves have been ruled) with the same groove spacing d.

The critical point is that the derivation above is purely geometrical. In the metallic case the strong response (that is, the production of real currents and hence strong electromagnetic radiation) is due to the free electrons in the metal. In a transmission grating the grooves (and the inter‐groove regions) have a different dielectric response; they do not have free electrons and instead polarize only weakly. Thus, while the same geometric phase–difference argument applies, the efficiency (and even the polarization state) of the radiated light may change. In a dielectric the “pulse” produced when the particle passes is typically weaker and may be shifted in phase because of the dielectric properties (in effect, there is an extra phase delay inside the glass determined by its index of refraction). In addition, one must also keep in mind that light propagating inside a dielectric travels at c/n rather than c. However, since the radiation we are considering is that which emerges from the grating into the free space (or is measured in the plane outside the grating), the basic interference condition [as given above] remains unchanged.

Thus, qualitatively, the effect is the same – the frequency-angle relationship is given by the same type of time‐delay (or “phase–matching”) condition – but the amplitude (and hence the overall intensity) of the emitted radiation, along with its polarization, may be quite different from that when a metal is used.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The frequency (or angular frequency) of the radiation observed at an angle θ (with respect to the particle’s direction) is given by

  ω = 2π m / [d (1/v – cos θ/c)],  or  f = m / [d (1/v – cos θ/c)],

with m = 1, 2, 3, … .

(b) Replacing the metallic grating by a transmission (dielectric) grating does not change the geometric (phase‐matching) condition that determines the frequency versus angle. However, because a dielectric does not support free conduction electrons, the strength of the induced currents (or dipoles) is different, and extra phase delays due to the refractive index may occur. Hence, while the frequency–angle relation remains much the same, the overall efficiency, intensity, and polarization of the emitted radiation can change qualitatively.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

\[\boxed{(a)\;\; f(\theta)=\frac{m}{d\left(\frac{1}{v}-\frac{\cos\theta}{c}\right)}\quad\text{with } m=1,2,\dots;\qquad (b)\;\; In\; a\; transmission\; grating the same geometric phase‐condition holds but the radiation’s efficiency, phase, and polarization are altered by the dielectric (non‐metallic) response.}\]

We will show that, by applying four‐momentum conservation to an electron initially at rest (energy m c², momentum 0) with an incoming photon of energy h f (momentum h f/c along +x) and by taking the scattered photon to emerge in the –y direction with energy h f′ (momentum h f′/c along –y), one may deduce the answers. (Here h is Planck’s constant and c is the speed of light.) We adopt a coordinate system with

  • incident photon along the +x axis,
  • scattered photon along –y,
  • thus the electron, by momentum conservation, must have momentum components

   pₓ = h f/c   (from x – conservation)
   p_y = h f′/c   (from y – conservation since initially p_y = 0 and the photon gives –h f′/c, so the electron must pick up +h f′/c).

Then the magnitude of the electron’s momentum is
  p = (h/c)√(f² + f′²).

Also, the electron’s direction (in the laboratory, i.e. the target’s rest frame) will be at an angle θ (measured from the initial photon direction) given by

  tanθ = p_y/pₓ = (h f′/c)/(h f/c) = f′/f.

A number of very similar answers are acceptable – one acceptable answer is given below.

────────────────────────
Step (a): Relating f′/f to θ

We have found from momentum conservation that

  tanθ = f′/f               (1)

so that

  f′/f = tanθ.
────────────────────────
Step (b): Finding the scattered electron’s total energy

Energy conservation tells us that
  (initial energy) = (final electron energy) + (final photon energy)

That is,
  m c² + h f = E_e + h f′        (2)

so that

  E_e = m c² + h (f – f′).

On the other hand the electron’s four‐momentum tells us that
  E_e² = m²c⁴ + p²c²
and since
  p² = (h²/c²)(f² + f′²),
we have
  E_e = √[m²c⁴ + h²(f² + f′²)].

It is a straightforward (if not terribly “pretty”) exercise to show that the two expressions are equivalent provided the kinematics is consistent. (In fact, if you square (2) and use (1) you will eventually arrive at the relation
  m c² (f – f′)= h f f′,
which is equivalent to the Compton‐formula for scattering into a right angle.) Either answer is acceptable. We then state

  E_e = √[m²c⁴ + h²(f² + f′²)]
or, equivalently,
  E_e = m c² + h (f – f′).
────────────────────────
Step (c): Finding the electron speed if the photon loses 0.2 of the electron’s rest energy

We are told that the energy “lost by the photon” is 0.2 m c²; that is,
  h(f – f′) = 0.2 m c².
But from (2) the electron’s kinetic energy is
  K_e = E_e – m c² = h(f – f′) = 0.2 m c².
Thus the electron’s total energy is
  E_e = m c² + 0.2 m c² = 1.2 m c²,
so that the Lorentz factor is
  γ = 1.2.

Since
  γ = 1/√(1 – v²/c²),
we have
  1 – v²/c² = 1/γ² = 1/(1.2)²,
and thus
  v = c √[1 – 1/(1.2)²].

Numerically, since 1/(1.2)² = 1/1.44 ≈ 0.6944, one obtains
  v ≈ c √(1 – 0.6944) = c √(0.3056) ≈ 0.5533 c.
────────────────────────
Step (d): Electron energy as measured by an observer O moving in the x‑direction with speed u

An observer O moving at speed u in the x‑direction (that is, along the incident photon direction) will measure the electron’s energy using a Lorentz transformation. In the lab (target) frame the scattered electron has total energy
  E_e = γ(v) m c²
and momentum
  p_e = γ(v) m v,
with an x‐component (since the electron’s momentum is p = (h f/c, h f′/c) and its direction makes an angle θ with the x‑axis) given by
  pₓ = γ(v) m v cosθ.

Then the Lorentz transformation (boost in the x‐direction) gives the energy observed by O as
  E'_e = γ(u)[E_e – u pₓ],
or, equivalently,
  E'_e = γ(u) [γ(v) m c² – u γ(v) m v cosθ]
      = γ(u) γ(v) m [ c² – u v cosθ],
with
  γ(u) = 1/√(1 – u²/c²)  and  γ(v) = 1/√(1 – v²/c²).

This is the answer written entirely in terms of m, v, u, and c.
────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) f′/f = tan θ. 

(b) The total energy of the scattered electron is
  E_e = √[m²c⁴ + h²(f² + f′²)]
or equivalently
  E_e = m c² + h (f – f′).

(c) If h(f – f′) = 0.2 m c² then the scattered electron has Lorentz‐factor γ = 1.2 and speed
  v = c √(1 – 1/(1.2)²) ≈ 0.55 c.

(d) An observer moving with speed u in the incident photon’s direction will measure the electron’s energy as
  E′_e = γ(u) [γ(v) m c² – u γ(v) m v cos θ]
        = γ(u) γ(v) m (c² – u v cos θ),
with γ(u) = 1/√(1 – u²/c²) and γ(v) = 1/√(1 – v²/c²).

We now box the final answers in LaTeX as requested.

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &\frac{f'}{f} = \tan\theta,\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &E_e = \sqrt{\,m^2c^4 + h^2\Bigl(f^2+f'^2\Bigr)}
\quad\text{(equivalently, }E_e = m c^2 + h\,(f-f')\text{)},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad &v = c\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{(1.2)^2}}\approx 0.55\,c,\\[1mm]
\text{(d)}\quad &E'_e = \gamma(u)\Bigl[\gamma(v)m c^2 - u\,\gamma(v)m v\cos\theta \Bigr]
=\gamma(u)\gamma(v)m\Bigl(c^2-uv\cos\theta\Bigr),
\quad\gamma(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2/c^2}}\,. 
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We start by writing an energy‐balance for the water heating system. In steady state the absorbed solar energy must equal the energy lost by thermal radiation from the panel’s front side (the only surface from which energy is lost since the other sides are perfect insulators).

Step 1. Note that if the panel has the same absorptance at all wavelengths then (by Kirchhoff’s law) its emissivity equals its absorptance. Let

  α = absorptance  
  ε = emissivity = α  
  I = incident solar irradiance = 800 W/m²  
  σ = Stefan–Boltzmann constant ≈ 5.67×10⁻⁸ W/m²·K⁴  
  T = equilibrium temperature of the water (in Kelvin).

Step 2. The energy absorbed per unit area is
  Q_in = α I.
The energy radiated per unit area is given by the Stefan–Boltzmann law:
  Q_out = ε σ T⁴.
At equilibrium, Q_in = Q_out. Therefore,
  α I = ε σ T⁴.
Since ε = α, the factors cancel, yielding
  α I = α σ T⁴  ⟹  T⁴ = I/σ.
Thus the equilibrium temperature is independent of α if the same factor applies for all wavelengths.

Step 3. Now substitute the given values:
  T⁴ = 800 W/m² ÷ (5.67×10⁻⁸ W/m²·K⁴) ≈ 1.409×10¹⁰ K⁴.
Taking the fourth root,
  T = (1.409×10¹⁰)^(1/4) ≈ 345 K.

Step 4. Now consider the case when the absorptance drops by half. Then the new absorptance is
  α_new = 0.96/2 = 0.48.
If the change is uniform with wavelength, then the emissivity also becomes
  ε_new = 0.48.
The energy balance now is:
  α_new I = ε_new σ T_new⁴.
Since ε_new = α_new, again the factor cancels:
  T_new⁴ = I/σ,
so that
  T_new = T = 345 K.

Thus, even though the panel absorbs less solar energy (and would seemingly “heat less”), it also loses less energy by radiation. When the absorptance (and therefore the emissivity) is reduced uniformly, the maximum steady‐state temperature remains unchanged.

Final Answer:
  \(\boxed{T\approx345\,K,\ \text{and a uniform halving of the absorptance does not change the equilibrium temperature.}}\)

We wish to determine the reflection and transmission (“Fresnel”) coefficients when an electromagnetic plane wave incident from a medium of index n₁ at an angle θ₁ reaches a planar interface with a medium of index n₂ (with the transmitted wave making an angle θ₂, fixed by Snell’s law: n₁sinθ₁ = n₂sinθ₂). Because the response depends on the polarization of the incident wave, it is usual to treat separately the two cases: 

• “s‐polarization” (or TE, where the electric field is perpendicular to the plane of incidence), and  
• “p‐polarization” (or TM, where the electric field lies in the plane of incidence). 

Below we go through the main steps and then state the final equations. We also show that for p–polarization one obtains Brewster’s law as the condition for zero reflection.

────────────────────────────
Step 1. The Boundary Conditions

At the interface the tangential components of the electric field E and the magnetic field H must be continuous. (Also the normal components of D and B obey appropriate continuity conditions, but here the tangential conditions are sufficient.) In addition, because there are two different polarizations, the field trial solutions must be written accordingly.

For a plane wave in a nonmagnetic medium (we assume permeability µ₁ = µ₂ = µ₀ for simplicity) the intrinsic impedance is proportional to 1/n. One must be careful about the relation between E and H when writing the boundary conditions.

────────────────────────────
Step 2. The Fresnel Coefficients

After writing down the incident, reflected, and transmitted fields and applying the boundary conditions at the planar interface, one obtains the following amplitude reflection and transmission coefficients:

1. For s–polarization (electric field perpendicular to the plane of incidence):

  Reflection coefficient:
    r₍s₎ = (n₁cosθ₁ – n₂cosθ₂) / (n₁cosθ₁ + n₂cosθ₂)

  Transmission coefficient:
    t₍s₎ = (2n₁cosθ₁) / (n₁cosθ₁ + n₂cosθ₂)

2. For p–polarization (electric field in the plane of incidence):

  Reflection coefficient:
    r₍p₎ = (n₂cosθ₁ – n₁cosθ₂) / (n₂cosθ₁ + n₁cosθ₂)

  Transmission coefficient:
    t₍p₎ = (2n₁cosθ₁) / (n₂cosθ₁ + n₁cosθ₂)

Note that these formulas follow after matching both the tangential components of the electric and magnetic fields. (Omitting some algebraic details, these forms are standard; any answer equivalent to the forms above is correct.)

────────────────────────────
Step 3. Brewster’s Law

Brewster’s law refers to the phenomenon that for p–polarized light (TM polarization), there exists an incident angle (Brewster’s angle) at which no light is reflected; that is, r₍p₎ = 0.

Setting r₍p₎ equal to zero we must have

  n₂cosθ₁ – n₁cosθ₂ = 0   ⟹  n₂cosθ₁ = n₁cosθ₂.

Using Snell’s law (n₁sinθ₁ = n₂sinθ₂), a short algebra leads to the well–known Brewster's relation:

  tanθ_B = n₂/n₁        (Brewster’s angle)

Thus, when the incident angle θ₁ is chosen so that

  θ_B = arctan(n₂/n₁)

there will be no reflected p–polarized light.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer

In summary, the Fresnel equations for an electromagnetic wave incident at angle θ₁ from a medium of index n₁ onto a medium of index n₂ are

For s–polarization:
  r₍s₎ = (n₁cosθ₁ – n₂cosθ₂) / (n₁cosθ₁ + n₂cosθ₂),
  t₍s₎ = (2n₁cosθ₁) / (n₁cosθ₁ + n₂cosθ₂).

For p–polarization:
  r₍p₎ = (n₂cosθ₁ – n₁cosθ₂) / (n₂cosθ₁ + n₁cosθ₂),
  t₍p₎ = (2n₁cosθ₁) / (n₂cosθ₁ + n₁cosθ₂).

Brewster’s law follows from r₍p₎ = 0 and gives

  tanθ_B = n₂/n₁.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Box

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{For s-polarization:}\quad
&r_s=\frac{n_1\cos\theta_1 - n_2\cos\theta_2}{n_1\cos\theta_1 + n_2\cos\theta_2},\quad
t_s=\frac{2n_1\cos\theta_1}{n_1\cos\theta_1+n_2\cos\theta_2},\\[1ex]
\text{For p-polarization:}\quad
&r_p=\frac{n_2\cos\theta_1 - n_1\cos\theta_2}{n_2\cos\theta_1 + n_1\cos\theta_2},\quad
t_p=\frac{2n_1\cos\theta_1}{n_2\cos\theta_1+n_1\cos\theta_2},\\[1ex]
\text{and Brewster's law:}\quad
&\tan\theta_B=\frac{n_2}{n_1}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We are told that an ion of ¹²C emits a photon with wavelength λ = 500 nm (energy hν ≃ 2.5 eV) while the ions are in a plasma with kT = 20 eV and density n ≃ 10^24 m⁻³, and there is also a non‐uniform magnetic field up to about 1 Tesla.

Below we discuss:

────────────────────────────
Step 1. (a) Broadening Mechanisms

Several effects can broaden an atomic spectral line so that its observed width Δλ is larger than the “natural” linewidth (which is the intrinsic linewidth due to the finite lifetime of the excited state):

1. Natural (or Lifetime) Broadening:
 • Due to the Heisenberg uncertainty principle (ΔEΔt ~ ℏ), even an isolated atom has a finite linewidth. This is usually extremely small compared to other effects.

2. Thermal (Doppler) Broadening:
 • In a gas, atoms move with thermal velocities. Because of the Doppler effect, atoms moving toward or away from the observer shift the line frequency. In a Maxwellian distribution, this produces a Gaussian line shape with a width proportional to vₜₕ (the thermal speed). At kT = 20 eV the thermal speeds of the ions are not negligible.

3. Collisional (Pressure) Broadening:
 • At a density of 10²⁴ m⁻³, collisions between ions (or with electrons) occur frequently. These collisions can perturb the energy levels and thus broaden the line. The pressure‐induced broadening is particularly important in dense plasmas.

4. Magnetic (Zeeman) Broadening:
 • A magnetic field splits the degenerate energy levels (the Zeeman effect). If the field is non uniform spatially, different ions will experience different splittings, and the overall observed line will be broadened.

────────────────────────────
Step 2. (b) Order‐of‐Magnitude Estimate for Doppler Broadening

We now choose Doppler broadening and make an order‐of‐magnitude estimate.

For an emitter moving with thermal speed vₜₕ, the Doppler shift is given by

  Δλ ≈ λ (vₜₕ / c).

For a Maxwellian distribution the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the Doppler-broadened line is

  Δλ_D,FWHM = 2√(ln2) (vₜₕ/c) λ.

The thermal speed is given by

  vₜₕ = √(2kT/m).

For a ¹²C ion (approximately 12 atomic mass units) we have

  m ≈ 12 × 1.66 × 10⁻²⁷ kg ≃ 2.0 × 10⁻²⁶ kg.

Also, note that
  kT = 20 eV = 20 × 1.602 × 10⁻¹⁹ J ≃ 3.204 × 10⁻¹⁸ J.

Thus,
  vₜₕ = √[ (2 × 3.204 × 10⁻¹⁸ J) / (2.0 × 10⁻²⁶ kg) ]
     ≃ √(3.204 × 10⁸ m²/s²)
     ≃ 1.79 × 10⁴ m/s.

Now, using the Doppler FWHM formula,
  Δλ_D,FWHM = 2√(ln2) (vₜₕ / c) λ.

We have
  2√(ln2) = 2 × 0.8326 ≃ 1.6652,
  vₜₕ / c = (1.79 × 10⁴ m/s) / (3.0 × 10⁸ m/s) ≃ 5.97 × 10⁻⁵,
  and λ = 500 nm = 5.0 × 10⁻⁷ m.

So,
  Δλ_D,FWHM = 1.6652 × (5.97 × 10⁻⁵) × (5.0 × 10⁻⁷ m)
         ≃ 1.6652 × 2.985 × 10⁻¹¹ m
         ≃ 4.97 × 10⁻¹¹ m.

That is, roughly 5 × 10⁻¹¹ m or 0.05 nm.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer

Thus, (a) the observed linewidth may be broader due to natural broadening, thermal (Doppler) broadening, collisional (pressure) broadening, and Zeeman broadening from a non-uniform B-field. For (b) an order‐of‐magnitude calculation of the Doppler width gives

  Δλ ≃ 5 × 10⁻¹¹ m ≃ 0.05 nm.

\[
\boxed{\Delta \lambda \sim 5 \times 10^{-11}\,\text{m}\sim 0.05\,\text{nm}}
\]
