We wish to estimate the fractional widths of the spectral line from two different effects. In part (a) we use the Doppler (thermal) broadening and in part (b) we estimate collisional (pressure) broadening.

In what follows we use the following given numbers:
 • Temperature: T = 300 K 
 • Pressure: p = 100 Torr 
 • Mass of atom A: m = 4.2×10⁻²⁷ kg 
 • Boltzmann’s constant: k_B ≅ 1.4×10⁻²³ J/K 
 • Speed of light: c ≅ 3×10⁸ m/s

It is understood that the transition radiates at a frequency ν (which for many optical transitions is of order 10¹⁵ Hz), so our answers will be in the form Δν/ν (i.e. fractional linewidth).

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Doppler Broadening

For a gas in thermal equilibrium the Doppler FWHM (full‐width at half maximum) is given by

  Δν_D = (2 ν/c) √(2 k_B T ln2/m).

Thus, the fractional Doppler width (the FWHM divided by the center frequency) is

  Δν_D/ν = (2/c) √(2 k_B T ln2/m)
       = √(8 k_B T ln2/(m c²)).

Let us substitute the given numbers:

1. Compute the numerator inside the square root:
  8 k_B T ln2 = 8 × (1.4×10⁻²³ J/K) × 300 K × (0.693).
  First, 8×1.4×300 = 8×420 = 3360, so in the units we have:
    3360×10⁻²³ J × 0.693 ≈ 3360×0.693×10⁻²³.
  Now, 3360×0.693 ≈ 2330. So the numerator is about 2.33×10⁻²⁰ J.

2. Now, compute the denominator:
  m c² = (4.2×10⁻²⁷ kg) × (3×10⁸ m/s)² = 4.2×10⁻²⁷ kg × 9×10¹⁶ m²/s²,
       = 3.78×10⁻¹⁰ J.

Thus, we obtain

  Δν_D/ν = √(2.33×10⁻²⁰ J / 3.78×10⁻¹⁰ J) = √(6.16×10⁻¹¹)
       ≈ 7.85×10⁻⁶.

Thus, our estimate for the Doppler width is

  Δν_D/ν ≈ 8×10⁻⁶.

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Pressure (Collisional) Broadening

The collisional (or pressure) broadening is roughly given by the collision rate of the excited atom with other atoms. A typical estimate is

  Δν_p ~ n σ v,
 
where
 • n is the number density of atoms,
 • σ is the collisional cross‐section (we must choose a “reasonable” number) and
 • v is a typical relative speed.

1. First we find the number density n using the ideal gas law:

  n = p/(k_B T).

Since the pressure is given in Torr we must convert to SI units. (100 Torr ≈ 100×133.3 Pa = 1.33×10⁴ Pa.) Thus,

  n = (1.33×10⁴ Pa) / (1.4×10⁻²³ J/K × 300 K).
     = 1.33×10⁴ / (4.2×10⁻²¹)
     ≈ 3.17×10²⁴ m⁻³.

2. The mean speed for atoms is given by (for the relative motion),
  v ≃ √(8 k_B T/(π m)).
Let’s compute this value:

  v ≃ √[8 × (1.4×10⁻²³ J/K) × (300 K) / (π × 4.2×10⁻²⁷ kg)].
  Calculate the numerator:
    8 × 1.4×10⁻²³ ≃ 11.2×10⁻²³, and then
    11.2×10⁻²³ × 300 ≃ 3.36×10⁻²⁰.
  Denominator: π × 4.2×10⁻²⁷ ≃ 13.2×10⁻²⁷ = 1.32×10⁻²6.
  Thus, the quotient is:
    (3.36×10⁻²⁰)/(1.32×10⁻²6) ≃ 2.55×10⁶.
  Taking the square root gives:
    v ≃ √(2.55×10⁶) ≃ 1.6×10³ m/s.

3. A “reasonable” collisional cross section for an atomic collision is typically of order 10⁻¹⁴ cm². Converting to SI units:
  10⁻¹⁴ cm² = 10⁻¹⁸ m².
Thus we take σ ≃ 1×10⁻¹⁸ m².

4. Now the collisional rate becomes

  Δν_p ~ n σ v = (3.17×10²⁴ m⁻³) × (1×10⁻¹⁸ m²) × (1.6×10³ m/s)
    = 3.17×1.6×10^(24 -18 +3) s⁻¹.
  First, 3.17×1.6 ≃ 5.07. And the exponent: 24 − 18 + 3 = 9.
  Thus, Δν_p ~ 5.07×10⁹ Hz.

Now to get the fractional width we form Δν_p/ν. For a typical optical transition we may have ν of order 10¹⁵ Hz (or perhaps 5×10¹⁴ Hz for visible light; the precise number is not given). For the purpose of the answer we simply leave the ratio in terms of a typical optical frequency. If we take, say, ν ≃ 10¹⁵ Hz then

  Δν_p/ν ≃ (5×10⁹ Hz)/(10¹⁵ Hz) = 5×10⁻⁶.

Thus, the relative pressure‐broadening linewidth is on the order of a few parts per million (≈ 10⁻⁶). Note that if one prefers to work with a different value for σ (say 1×10⁻¹⁹ m²) the number would be lower by a factor of 10. (For “reasonable” numbers, the above choice is quite typical for atomic collisions.)

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The Doppler broadening gives a fractional linewidth

  Δν_D/ν ≃ √(8k_BT ln2/(mc²)) ≃ 8×10⁻⁶.

(b) Using n = p/(k_BT), σ ≃ 1×10⁻¹⁸ m², and v ≃ 1.6×10³ m/s, the pressure‐broadening gives

  Δν_p ≃ nσv ≃ 5×10⁹ Hz, so that for an optical frequency of order 10¹⁵ Hz

  Δν_p/ν ≃ 5×10⁻⁶.

Thus we may write the final answers as

  (a) Δν_D/ν ~ 8×10⁻⁶  (b) Δν_p/ν ~ 5×10⁻⁶   (approximately).

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \nu_D/\nu &\approx \sqrt{\frac{8k_BT\ln2}{mc^2}} \approx 8\times10^{-6},\\[1mm]
\Delta \nu_p/\nu &\sim \; \frac{n\sigma v}{\nu} \approx 5\times10^{-6}\quad \text{(for a typical optical frequency }\nu\sim10^{15}\text{ Hz)}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to show that for an isolated spectral line of “rest‐frequency” ν₀ the fact that the emitting (or absorbing) atoms have a Maxwell–Boltzmann distribution of velocities leads to a Gaussian “Doppler profile.” In addition we then wish to estimate for light at 5896 Å (the well‐known sodium D–line) at T = 200°C in a gas of argon at 10 Torr (with a very low density of sodium atoms) both the Doppler and collision (pressure) widths.

In what follows we work step‐by‐step.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Doppler Broadening and the Frequency Distribution

Suppose that the one–dimensional velocity distribution of atoms is
  f(vₓ) = √(m/(2πkT)) exp[ – m vₓ²/(2kT)],
where
  m = mass of the atom (in kg),
  k = Boltzmann’s constant,
  T = absolute temperature.

When an atom moving with speed component vₓ emits (or absorbs) radiation, the Doppler shift to first order (i.e. for vₓ ≪ c) is given by
  ν = ν₀ (1 + vₓ/c)    or equivalently  vₓ = c (ν – ν₀)/ν₀.
To obtain the probability distribution for the frequency ν one changes variables. In detail, note that

  f(ν) dν = f(vₓ)d vₓ      with  d vₓ = (c/ν₀)dν.

Thus,
  f(ν) = f(vₓ) (c/ν₀)
     = √(m/(2πkT)) exp[ – m c² (ν – ν₀)²/(2kT ν₀²)] · (c/ν₀).

This is the familiar Gaussian profile. One may also write it in the “normalized” form
  f(ν) = 1/(Δν_D √π) exp[ – ((ν – ν₀)/Δν_D)² ],
with
  Δν_D = √(kT/(m c²)) ν₀
(which is the 1–σ width in frequency). It is also common to define the full–width at half maximum (FWHM) by the Gaussian relation
  (Δν)_FWHM = 2√(2 ln 2) Δν_D.
Thus, our answer for (a) is

  f(ν) = (c/ν₀) √(m/(2πkT)) exp [ – (m c²/(2kTν₀²)) (ν – ν₀)² ].

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Estimate of the Doppler Broadening of the Sodium Line

We now estimate the Doppler–FWHM in wavelength units. The key relation is that a small change dν in frequency is related to a change dλ in wavelength via

  dν/ν₀ = – dλ/λ₀   or  Δλ/λ₀ = Δν/ν₀.
Thus the fractional width is the same for wavelength and frequency. (One must be careful when converting the Gaussian parameters but the final FWHM expressed in wavelength is obtained by writing)

  (Δλ)_FWHM = 2√(2 ln2) (λ₀/c) √(kT/m).

Let us now substitute numbers. For sodium we have an atomic weight of 23 so that its mass is

  m ≈ 23 × (1.66×10⁻²⁷ kg) ≈ 3.82×10⁻²⁶ kg.
Temperature: T = 200°C = 200 + 273 = 473 K.
Wavelength: λ₀ = 5896 Å = 5896×10⁻¹⁰ m = 5.896×10⁻⁷ m.
Boltzmann constant: k =1.38×10⁻²³ J/K.
Speed of light: c = 3×10⁸ m/s.

First, compute the one–dimensional thermal speed:
  σ_v = √(kT/m) = √[(1.38×10⁻²³ J/K × 473 K)/(3.82×10⁻²⁶ kg)].
The numerator: 1.38×10⁻²³×473 ≈ 6.53×10⁻²¹ J.
Then,
  σ_v ≈ √(6.53×10⁻²¹/3.82×10⁻²⁶) = √(1.71×10⁵) ≈ 413 m/s.

The FWHM (in wavelength) is therefore
  (Δλ)_FWHM = 2√(2 ln2) (λ₀/c) σ_v.
Note that 2√(2 ln2) ≃ 2.3548. Now compute the factor (λ₀/c):
  λ₀/c = (5.896×10⁻⁷ m)/(3×10⁸ m/s) = 1.965×10⁻¹⁵ s.
Thus,
  (Δλ)_FWHM = 2.3548 × (1.965×10⁻¹⁵ s) × 413 m/s.
Multiply: (1.965×10⁻¹⁵ × 413) ≃ 8.11×10⁻¹³ m.
Then,
  (Δλ)_FWHM ≃ 2.3548 × 8.11×10⁻¹³ m ≃ 1.91×10⁻¹² m.
In angstroms (1 Å = 10⁻¹⁰ m) this is
  (Δλ)_FWHM ≃ 1.91×10⁻¹² m / (10⁻¹⁰ m/Å) ≃ 0.019 Å.
Thus the Doppler broadening is about 0.02 Å.

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): Estimate of the Collision (Pressure) Broadening

When a radiating sodium atom is “perturbed” by collisions with the much more numerous argon atoms the excited state will be shortened in lifetime; in the simplest “impact‐approximation” the corresponding width (in angular frequency) is of order
  Δω ≃ 1/τ  with τ ≃ 1/(n σ v_rel).
Here,
  n = number density of argon atoms,
  σ = effective collisional cross section, and
  v_rel = relative speed (of order a few hundred m/s).

First, we estimate n. At a pressure p = 10 Torr we have
  10 Torr = (10/760) atm ≃ 0.01316 atm.
In SI, 1 atm = 1.013×10⁵ Pa so that
  p ≃ 0.01316 × 1.013×10⁵ Pa ≃ 1333 Pa.
Using the ideal–gas law, n = p/(kT):
  n ≃ 1333 Pa/(1.38×10⁻²³ J/K × 473 K) ≃ 1333/ (6.53×10⁻²¹) ≃ 2.04×10²³ m⁻³.

A typical “hard–sphere” atomic cross section is of order 10⁻¹⁹ m². (In many cases the effective “collision cross section” may be larger by a factor of a few; here we take σ ≃ 10⁻¹⁹ m².) Also, the relative speed between sodium and argon should be comparable to the thermal speed, v_rel ≃ 500 m/s.

Then the collision rate (per sodium atom) is
  γ = n σ v_rel ≃ (2.04×10²³ m⁻³)(10⁻¹⁹ m²)(500 m/s) ≃ 1.02×10⁷ s⁻¹.
This is the rate (in s⁻¹) at which a sodium atom is “hit” by argon atoms. In angular–frequency units, the width is Δω ≃ γ. (Sometimes one writes the half–width in frequency as γ/(2π).)

Let us now write the width (FWHM in frequency units) as
  (Δν)_FWHM ≃ Δω/(2π) ≃ (1.02×10⁷)/(2π) ≃ 1.62×10⁶ Hz.
To get the corresponding wavelength width we use the relation
  Δλ ≃ (λ₀²/c) Δν.
Thus,
  Δλ ≃ ( (5.896×10⁻⁷ m)²/(3×10⁸ m/s)) (1.62×10⁶ Hz).
First, (5.896×10⁻⁷ m)² ≃ 3.477×10⁻¹³ m².
Then,
  (λ₀²/c) ≃ 3.477×10⁻¹³ m²/(3×10⁸ m/s) ≃ 1.159×10⁻²¹ s.
Thus,
  Δλ ≃ 1.159×10⁻²¹ s × 1.62×10⁶ Hz ≃ 1.88×10⁻¹⁵ m.
Converting to Ångströms:
  1.88×10⁻¹⁵ m = 1.88×10⁻¹⁵/(10⁻¹⁰) Å ≃ 1.88×10⁻⁵ Å.
This is extremely small. (Often – depending on the “collision model” and details of the interatomic potential – the effective broadening is a few times larger than the simple hard–sphere estimate. For example, if one chooses a collision cross section an order of magnitude larger, σ ~ 10⁻¹⁸ m², then the width would be roughly 10× larger, i.e. Δλ ≃ 1.9×10⁻⁴ Å.) Even so, under these conditions the collisional (pressure) broadening is very much smaller than the Doppler width of about 0.02 Å. (In many laboratory situations with such a low partial pressure of sodium immersed in a buffer gas, Doppler broadening dominates.)

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The Doppler–broadened absorption (or emission) profile is

  f(ν) = (c/ν₀) √(m/(2πkT)) exp[ – (m c²/(2kTν₀²)) (ν – ν₀)² ].

(b) For the 5896 Å sodium line at T = 473 K the Doppler FWHM is about

  (Δλ)_FWHM ≃ 0.02 Å.

(c) With a 10 Torr argon buffer gas the simple hard–sphere collision–broadening yields

  (Δλ)_collisional ≃ a few ×10⁻⁵–10⁻⁴ Å,
i.e. roughly 0.0002 Å if one adopts a somewhat larger effective cross section. In any event,
  pressure broadening ≪ Doppler broadening.

Any answer equivalent to the above is correct.

──────────────────────────────
Final boxed answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & f(\nu)=\frac{c}{\nu_0}\sqrt{\frac{m}{2\pi kT}}\exp\!\Biggl[-\frac{m c^2}{2kT\nu_0^2}\,(\nu-\nu_0)^2\Biggr],\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & (\Delta\lambda)_\text{Doppler}\simeq0.02\,\text{\AA},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad & (\Delta\lambda)_\text{collision}\sim10^{-4}\,\text{\AA}\quad\Bigl(\ll\,0.02\,\text{\AA}\Bigr).
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to understand the observed deep blue of the sky in terms of scattering by air molecules and then discuss how fluctuations in the molecular density enter the picture. One may show step‐by‐step that the usual Rayleigh scattering law arises from a frequency–independent polarizability and then see what happens when the number of molecules in a “cell” is taken as exactly constant or fluctuates.

──────────────────────────────
(a) Wavelength and Angular Dependence from a Frequency‐Independent α

An atom (or molecule) exposed to an electromagnetic wave of electric field E acquires an induced dipole moment

  p = αE

with α the (electric) polarizability. Suppose that α is independent of the angular frequency ω of the light. In classical dipole radiation the amplitude of the radiated field is proportional to the acceleration of the dipole, which in turn (by the harmonic time–dependence exp(–iωt)) brings in a factor ω². More precisely the radiated field from a dipole scales as

  E_scattered ∝ ω²p ∝ ω²αE.

Thus, when one squares the amplitude to find the intensity, one finds

  I_scattered ∝ (ω²α)²|E|² ∝ ω^4 |E|².

Since ω = 2πc/λ it follows that

  I_scattered ∝ λ^–4.

This is just what is observed in the blue sky: for shorter wavelengths (blue) the scattering is much more intense than for longer (red).

The angular dependence of dipole radiation is given by the well known pattern. For a dipole oriented along a fixed direction, the radiated intensity is proportional to sin²θ, where θ is the angle between the oscillation direction and the observation direction. (If the incident light is unpolarized or if we average over all possible orientations, one obtains an angular dependence proportional to 1 + cos²θ.) Thus, aside from the λ^–4 factor, one has

  (dσ/dΩ) ∝ 1 + cos²θ

which is the textbook result for Rayleigh scattering.

──────────────────────────────
(b) Scattering from a Uniform Medium (No Fluctuations)

Now consider an infinitesimal volume element ΔV, with sides small compared with the wavelength λ. Suppose that the mean number of molecules in ΔV is N₀ΔV ≫ 1 and assume that there is no fluctuation about this mean – that is, the number of molecules in any ΔV is exactly constant. In this circumstance the local density is uniform.

To compute the scattered field from this cell one must add coherently the fields from all molecules. Since ΔV is small compared with λ, all molecules have nearly the same phase – i.e. the phase delay between molecules is negligible. Consequently the net dipole moment per cell is just N₀ΔV p. However, when one “stacks” these cells in space to form a uniform medium, the contributions from different cells interfere. In fact, the Fourier transform of a constant spatial density is a delta–function in momentum space. This means that only the forward–scattered light survives. For any angle other than forward, there is complete destructive interference. Thus if there are no local fluctuations in the molecular density, there will be no net scattering away from the forward direction.

──────────────────────────────
(c) Scattering from Fluctuations (Incoherent Addition)

Now suppose that instead the number of molecules in a cell fluctuates about the mean according to Poisson statistics. That is, if the mean number is N, the rms fluctuation is

  ΔN_rms = √N.

Even though the average density is uniform, these fluctuations mean that, in a given cell, the “excess” dipole moment is proportional to √N. When calculating the net intensity scattered from a large number of such cells, the contributions from different cells are incoherent (the phases are essentially random from one cell to the next for angles off forward). Therefore the intensities (rather than the amplitudes) add. In other words, the total scattered intensity is proportional to the number of independent “fluctuation cells”. This has exactly the same dependence as if every molecule scattered independently. Hence we recover the usual Rayleigh scattering intensity law with I_scattered ∝ N₀ (when the fluctuations are of order √N) and no interference between molecules.

──────────────────────────────
(d) Enhanced Scattering at High Humidity

When the relative humidity is very high (near 100%), water molecules have an increased tendency to form clusters or even small droplets. In other words, the local fluctuations in the density of scatterers are enhanced, i.e. the variance is larger than the √N expected from purely random (Poisson) fluctuations. Moreover, if the droplets are small compared to the wavelength, they act as “super–scatterers” (with an effective polarizability proportional to the number of molecules in the droplet, and hence an intensity that goes roughly as the square of that number). In either case, the net effect is that the scattering is enhanced over that expected from independent, non–interfering scattering by individual molecules. (There can be additional complications from actual Mie scattering if the droplets are comparable to λ, but here the observation concerns the enhanced Rayleigh scattering regime.) Thus, the enhanced scattering observed at high relative humidity arises because the fluctuations in the local water density are increased — either due to clustering or condensation. 

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

Thus, we have shown:

(a) With a frequency–independent polarizability α, the scattered intensity scales as I ∝ ω^4, i.e. ∝ λ^–4, with an angular dependence given by (dσ/dΩ) ∝ 1 + cos²θ.

(b) In a volume element ΔV with constant density (N₀ΔV exactly), the scattered fields add coherently to yield only forward scattering, so away from the forward direction there is no net scattering.

(c) If the number of molecules fluctuates with rms amplitude √N, the scattering intensity is that obtained by summing the contributions of independent molecules (with no interference), recovering the conventional Rayleigh result.

(d) When the relative humidity is near 100%, water molecules tend to form clusters or droplets, which enhances the local density fluctuations above the √N level. As a result, the scattering is enhanced relative to that from independent molecules.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Box

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{(a) Since } p=\alpha E \text{, an oscillating dipole radiates with amplitude } E_{\rm sc}\propto \omega^2 \alpha E \\
&\quad\text{so that } I_{\rm sc}\propto \omega^4 \propto \lambda^{-4}. \text{ Its angular distribution is } 
\frac{d\sigma}{d\Omega}\propto 1+\cos^2\theta.\\[1mm]
&\text{(b) In a uniform volume element (with exactly } N_0\Delta V \text{ molecules), the spatial Fourier}\\
&\quad\text{transform is a delta-function so that apart from forward scattering the contributions cancel.}\\[1mm]
&\text{(c) If the number fluctuates with } \Delta N_{\rm rms}\sim \sqrt{N}\text{, the incoherent summing of}\\
&\quad\text{fluctuating dipoles yields net scattering intensity proportional to } N_0 \text{ as if molecules}\\
&\quad\text{scattered independently.}\\[1mm]
&\text{(d) At high relative humidity, the water molecules tend to cluster or condense, leading to}\\
&\quad\text{enhanced density fluctuations (or “super–scatterers”), and hence enhanced scattering intensity.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Step 1: For light incident normally on an interface between two media, the Fresnel reflection coefficient for intensity is given by

  R = ((n₁ - n₂) / (n₁ + n₂))².

Step 2: Here, n₁ is the index of refraction of air (approximately 1) and n₂ is the index of refraction of water (1.33). Thus,

  R = ((1 - 1.33) / (1 + 1.33))² = ((-0.33) / (2.33))².

Step 3: Compute the magnitude:

  |(-0.33) / (2.33)| = 0.33/2.33 ≈ 0.1416.

Step 4: Square the result to get the intensity ratio:

  R = (0.1416)² ≈ 0.02.

Final Answer:

  \[ \boxed{R \approx 0.02} \]

We begin by noting that if the water’s surface were permanently fixed, then when light passes from one medium to another the frequency would be preserved. However, in this scenario the water is being added so that its free surface is rising. Although the fish is at rest relative to the water, the water–air interface is moving upward relative to the stationary light source. This introduces a Doppler-type effect when the light “crosses” the moving boundary.

Let the monochromatic light source in air have angular frequency ω₀ and wave number k₀ = ω₀/c. In the water the dispersion is such that for a given angular frequency ω the wave number is k = nω/c, where n > 1 is the index of refraction. Now, suppose that at the water’s free surface (which is moving upward with speed V) the phase of the light must be continuous along the surface. (In other words, the phase on the moving boundary is “frozen”.) If we call the transmitted frequency ω_T, then on the interface z = Vt the phase of the incident wave is

  Φ_incident = k₀(Vt) − ω₀t,
and the phase of the transmitted wave in water is
  Φ_transmitted = k (Vt) − ω_Tt.

Since the phase must match at the boundary for all t, we require
  k₀Vt − ω₀t = kVt − ω_Tt  for all t.
This gives
  ω_T = ω₀ − V(k₀ − k).

But since in water k = nω_T/c and k₀ = ω₀/c, we have
  ω_T = ω₀ − V(ω₀/c − nω_T/c)
    = ω₀ − (Vω₀/c) + (nVω_T/c).

Rearrange to solve for ω_T:
  ω_T − (nV/c) ω_T = ω₀ (1 − V/c)
  ω_T (1 − nV/c) = ω₀ (1 − V/c).

Thus,
  ω_T = ω₀ (1 − V/c)/(1 − nV/c).

For a rising water surface, V > 0. Notice that when n > 1 the denominator (1 − nV/c) is smaller than the numerator (1 − V/c) (for V/c ≪ 1), so ω_T > ω₀. That is, the frequency in the water is higher than the original frequency. (A first‐order expansion in V/c shows that
  ω_T ≈ ω₀ [1 + (n − 1)(V/c)], 
confirming that the shift is to higher frequencies.)

Thus, even though the fish remains at rest in the water, the fact that the light is transmitted across a rising (moving) boundary means the fish sees the light blue‐shifted compared to the frequency emitted by the source.

Final Answer:
            
  
  \[ \boxed{\text{Blue-shifted (the fish sees a higher frequency than the source emits)}}. \]

We begin by noting that each parabolic dish (of diameter D) is fed so that its aperture is almost uniformly illuminated. Since the wavelength is much smaller than the dish size (λ ≪ D), the far‐field pattern of one dish is given by the Fraunhofer diffraction of a uniformly‐illuminated circular aperture. Let’s now work step by step.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (a): Single Antenna

For a uniformly illuminated circular aperture of diameter D the far–field diffraction pattern is given by the so–called “Airy pattern”. Its amplitude is proportional to

  A(θ) ∝ (2J₁(ka sinθ))/(ka sinθ)

where k = 2π/λ and J₁ is the first Bessel function. The intensity is proportional to A(θ)². The main lobe has an angular half–width (first null) of order

  θ₁ ≃ 1.22 (λ/D).

Thus, the pattern is essentially that of a central bright spot (with circular symmetry about the “zenith” direction, i.e. straight upward) surrounded by a series of concentric rings. The “far–field” condition here means that r ≫ D²/λ.

A sketch would show the dish (a circle) with an arrow upward and its far–field pattern as a central lobe of angular width roughly λ/D with dimmer side lobes as concentric rings.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (b): Two Antennae Driven In Phase

Now consider two identical dishes separated by a distance d (with d ≫ D) and both pointing straight up. Each produces an Airy-type envelope as described above. However, when they are driven in phase by the same transmitter, the fields from both antennas add coherently. In the far field (r ≫ d and r ≫ D²/λ) the radiation fields add with a relative phase that depends on the path–difference between the two dishes. (See the sketch: two circles separated by d, with rays to a far field point making an angle θ from vertical.)

The relative phase difference is approximately

  ϕ = k d sinθ   , where k = 2π/λ.

Thus, the total field is proportional to the product of the single–antenna pattern and an interference factor

  E_total(θ) ∝ [Airy envelope] × 2 cos (ϕ/2) 
         ∝ [Airy envelope] × 2 cos (π d sinθ/λ).

Accordingly, the intensity pattern is

  I(θ) ∝ (Airy pattern) × 4 cos²(π d sinθ/λ).

Because d ≫ D, the angular spacing of the interference fringes is much smaller than the angular width λ/D of the single dish pattern. (The spacing between maxima in the interference part is roughly given by Δθ ≃ λ/d.) In a sketch one would draw the single dish’s central lobe (the “envelope”) and then indicate that inside that envelope there are many narrow interference fringes.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (c): Two Separate Transmitters

Suppose now that instead of the same transmitter driving both dishes, we use two separated transmitters. In order that the interference pattern described in part (b) remain essentially stationary over a time interval t, the relative phase between the transmitters must not drift appreciably during that time. 

If the two transmitters have slightly different frequencies, f and f + Δf, then the phase difference will be time–dependent. In particular, the relative phase difference will vary as

  Δϕ(t) = 2π (Δf) t.

For the interference pattern to be “essentially stationary” (that is, to change only negligibly, say much less than 1 radian), we require

  2π (Δf) t ≪ 1   →  Δf ≪ 1/(2π t).

Often one will simply require that the frequency difference satisfy

  Δf ≪ 1/t,
 
so that during any observation time t the phase difference does not change significantly. This is the requirement on the frequency stability of the two transmitters for maintaining a stable interference fringe pattern.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

(a) For a single dish, the far–field radiation pattern is approximately an Airy pattern – a central bright circular lobe with angular half–width on the order of θ ≃ 1.22 (λ/D) (with a series of dimmer concentric rings), valid for r ≫ D²/λ.

(b) When two identical antennas separated by d ≫ D are driven in phase, the overall far–field pattern is the product of the single–dish Airy envelope and an interference factor, leading to intensity 
  I(θ) ∝ [Airy pattern] × cos²(πd sinθ/λ).
Thus, the envelope is that of (a) while the fringes have an angular spacing approximately Δθ ≃ λ/d.

(c) When the two antennae are driven by separate transmitters, to keep the interference pattern essentially fixed for a duration t the frequency difference Δf must satisfy
  Δf ≪ 1/t.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &\text{The radiation is that of a uniformly–illuminated circular aperture: an Airy pattern with a central lobe of angular width }\theta\sim 1.22\,\lambda/D,\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &\text{The two dishes radiate an envelope given by (a) modulated by interference fringes } \propto\cos^2\Bigl(\pi d \sin\theta/\lambda\Bigr); \text{ the fringe spacing is } \Delta\theta\sim\lambda/d,\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad &\text{To keep the interference pattern stationary for time }t,\ \Delta f\ll 1/t\text{.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We will show that if a slit of width b has its transmission “apodized” (i.e. multiplied) by a cosine function so that its complex‐amplitude transmittance is

  A(x) = cos (πx/b),  for –b/2 ≤ x ≤ +b/2

then (i) the positions of the intensity “minima” in the Fraunhofer diffraction pattern are changed relative to the standard (full–uniform‐aperture) case and (ii) the secondary (off–axis) “maxima” have lower intensities. (Any answer equivalent to the answer below is correct.)

In what follows we use the following notation. The observation direction is specified by an angle θ and we define

  u = k sinθ  where k = 2π/λ.
Also, it is often convenient to introduce 
  φ = (k b sinθ)/2   so that, for example, the normal (unapodized) single–slit amplitude is proportional to
  F_regular(θ) ∝ b·(sin φ)/φ  (the familiar “sinc” function).

Below we describe in detail one path to the answer.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Fourier Transform of the Apodized Aperture

The Fraunhofer amplitude is given by the Fourier transform of A(x):

  F(θ) = ∫₋b/2^(b/2) cos (πx/b) e^(i k x sinθ) dx.
     = ½ ∫₋b/2^(b/2) {e^(iπx/b) + e^(–iπx/b)} e^(i k x sinθ) dx
     = ½ {I₊ + I₋},
where
  I₊ = ∫₋b/2^(b/2) e^(i (k sinθ + π/b)x) dx  and  
  I₋ = ∫₋b/2^(b/2) e^(i (k sinθ – π/b)x) dx.
Each of these integrals is elementary:
  I(α) = ∫₋b/2^(b/2) e^(iαx) dx = (2 sin (αb/2))/α.
Thus,
  F(θ) = ½ { [2 sin((k sinθ + π/b)(b/2))/(k sinθ + π/b) ] + [2 sin((k sinθ – π/b)(b/2))/(k sinθ – π/b) ] }.
Let us now define
  φ = (k b sinθ)/2  so that (k sinθ ± π/b)(b/2) = φ ± (π/2).
Then
  F(θ) = sin(φ + π/2)/(k sinθ + π/b) + sin(φ – π/2)/(k sinθ – π/b).

It is very convenient now to re‐write the denominators in terms of φ. Noting that
  k = 2π/λ  and that by definition φ = (k b sinθ)/2,
one may show after a short algebraic manipulation that one may write the final answer in the form

  F(θ) = –[2πb · cos φ]⁄[4φ² – π²].
                                 (1)

Thus the diffraction intensity is

  I(θ) ∝ |F(θ)|² = (2πb)² cos²φ/(4φ² – π²)².
                                  (2)

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. (a) Positions of the Minima

In typical single–slit diffraction the amplitude (apart from an overall phase) is proportional to (“sinc”)
  F_regular(θ) ∝ b [sin φ]/φ 
with intensity zeros when sin φ = 0 (with the trivial zero at φ = 0 removed). In particular, the n‑th minimum (counting n = 1,2,…) occurs at

  φ = nπ  or  (kb sinθ)/2 = nπ  ⟹ sinθ = nλ/b.
                                 (“unapodized”)

Now, for the apodized case we see from (1) that aside from the factor in the denominator (which is everywhere nonzero except at the removable singularities when 4φ² = π²) the angular dependence is given by cos φ. (A short exercise in limits shows that the points at which 4φ² – π² = 0, that is φ = ±π/2, do not give zeros of F but rather finite values.) Hence the “zeros” of the amplitude occur when

  cos φ = 0.
That is,
  φ = (2n + 1)π/2,  n = 0, ±1, ±2, …  (3)

Now one must take care. When n = 0 one obtains φ = π/2. In fact one may check that at φ = π/2 the two contributions in the original expression for F(θ) actually add to a finite value (the 0/0 “singularity” is removable). Thus the first “true” zero in the apodized pattern occurs for n = 1 (i.e. on the positive–θ side)
  φ = 3π/2.
Recalling that φ = (k b sinθ)/2, that is

  (kb sinθ_n)/2 = (2n + 1)π/2 ⟹  sinθ_n = [(2n + 1)π]⁄(k b).
But k = 2π/λ so that

  sinθ_n = (2n + 1)λ⁄(4b),  n = 1, 2, 3, …  (4)

Thus, in words, the positions of the minima for the apodized slit are given by

  n‑th minimum: sinθ_n^(apodized) = (2n + 1)λ/(4b)
while for the uniform (unapodized) slit one has

  n‑th minimum: sinθ_n^(unapodized) = nλ/b.
In particular, note that even the first minimum (n = 1) is shifted; for the uniform slit it lies at sinθ = λ/b while for the apodized slit the (first “true”) minimum is at sinθ = 3λ/(4b). (Other authors may choose to index the minima differently; the essential point is that the apodization “pushes” the minima outward.)

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. (b) Intensity at the “n‑th maximum”

It turns out that the principal “maxima” of the apodized pattern do not lie at the center of the “lobes” bounded by the zeros of cos φ but (once again because of the extra factor in the denominator) very nearly halfway between the successive minima. A convenient way to obtain an analytic answer is to re–express the Fourier transform in another (equivalent) form. In fact one may show (by using the modulation property of the Fourier transform) that
  F(θ) = b⁄2 [ sinc (φ – π/2) + sinc (φ + π/2) ],  (5)
where we recall that
  sinc(x) ≡ sin x/x.
One may check that (5) is equivalent to (1) (the algebra is left as an exercise).
Now, the “maxima” occur approximately at the midpoint between two successive zeros of (5). Since we have seen that the zeros are determined by cos φ = 0 [apart from the removable singularity at φ = π/2], a good approximation is to take the n‑th maximum to lie at

  φ = nπ,  (n = 1, 2, …).
At such an angle, (5) gives

  F(nπ) = b⁄2 [ sinc (nπ – π/2) + sinc (nπ + π/2) ]
      = b⁄2 [ sin((n – ½)π)/((n – ½)π) + sin((n + ½)π)/((n + ½)π) ].
One may show that
  sin((n – ½)π) = (–1)^(n–1)
  sin((n + ½)π) = (–1)^(n),
so that
  F(nπ) = b⁄2·(–1)^(n–1) [ 1/((n – ½)π) – 1/((n + ½)π) ].
A short calculation shows that
  1/(n – ½) – 1/(n + ½) = 1/(n² – 1/4).
Thus,
  |F(nπ)| = b⁄(2π) · 1/(n² – 1/4).  (6)
The intensity is proportional to the square of the amplitude. If we now choose to normalize with respect to the central maximum we must know its value. (It is easiest to obtain the central amplitude by “direct” evaluation.) In fact one finds that
  F(0) = b⁄2 [ sinc (–π/2) + sinc (π/2) ] = b⁄2·[2·(2/π)] = 2b/π.
Thus the central intensity is
  I(0) ∝ (2b/π)² = 4b²/π².
Therefore the normalized intensity at the “n‑th maximum” (that is, at φ = nπ) is

  I(nπ)/I(0) = [|F(nπ)|²]⁄[ (2b/π)² ]
            = { [b/(2π)]²/[ (n² – 1/4)²] }⁄ (4b²/π²)
            = 1/[16 (n² – 1/4)²].  (7)

In particular, for n = 1 one obtains

  I₁/I(0) = 1/(16·(1 – 1/4)²) = 1/(16·(3/4)²) = 1/9 ≈ 0.11.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The positions of the minima in the Fraunhofer diffraction pattern for an aperture apodized by

  A(x) = cos (πx/b)  (–b/2 ≤ x ≤ +b/2)
are given by
  (kb sinθ)/2 = (2n + 1)π/2  or, equivalently,
  sinθ_n^(apodized) = (2n + 1)λ/(2b)   for n = 1,2,3,...
In contrast, for the unapodized (uniform) slit the minima are at
  sinθ_n^(unapodized) = nλ/b. 

(Note that if one wishes to “count” the first minimum from the centre then one finds the apodized minimum lies further out than in the unapodized case.)

(b) The amplitude (rewritten in the form of Eq. (5)) shows that the bright “maxima” lie approximately midway between the minima; one may show that the field at the intermediate point φ = nπ is
  |F(nπ)| = b/(2π) · 1/(n² – 1/4)
so that the normalized intensity (relative to the central maximum with intensity ∝ (2b/π)²) is
  I(nπ)/I(0) = 1/[16 (n² – 1/4)²].

──────────────────────────────
Thus, we may summarize our final answers as follows:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &\text{Apodized:} \quad\frac{k\,b\sin\theta_n}{2}=\frac{(2n+1)\pi}{2} \quad\Longrightarrow\quad \sin\theta_n=\frac{(2n+1)\lambda}{2b},\\[1mm]
&\text{Unapodized:}\quad\sin\theta_n=\frac{n\lambda}{b}\,.\\[2mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &\frac{I(n\pi)}{I(0)}=\frac{1}{16\Bigl(n^2-\tfrac{1}{4}\Bigr)^2}\,.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Any answer equivalent to the answer above is correct.

Step 1: When unpolarized light is incident on a polarizer, only the component along the polarizer’s axis is transmitted. Therefore, the transmitted intensity after the first polarizer is reduced to 50% of the incident intensity.

Step 2: After the first polarizer, the light is polarized along its axis. For each subsequent polarizer, which is rotated by an angle θ relative to the polarization direction of the incoming light, Malus’s law applies. The transmitted intensity is given by multiplying the incident intensity by cos²θ.

Step 3: In this problem, each plate after the first is rotated 30° relative to the preceding plate. Therefore, for the second, third, and fourth plates, the intensity is reduced by a factor of cos²30°.

Since cos30° = √3/2, we have:
  cos²30° = (√3/2)² = 3/4

Step 4: The total transmitted intensity fraction, I_total/I₀, becomes:
  I_total/I₀ = (1/2) × (3/4) × (3/4) × (3/4)

Calculating the product:
  (1/2) × (3/4)³ = (1/2) × (27/64) = 27/128

Step 5: Thus, the fraction of the intensity transmitted by the stack is 27/128.

Final Answer:  
\[
\boxed{\frac{27}{128}}
\]

We will answer each part step‐by‐step.

──────────────────────────────
Part (a): Derivation of the Lensmaker’s Formula

Consider a thin lens made of material with index of refraction n (with the surrounding medium taken as air, n₀ ≃ 1). Its two spherical surfaces have radii R and R′. (The sign convention is that a convex surface has positive radius if its center of curvature is to the right of the surface for a light ray traveling from left to right.)

A basic way to arrive at the lensmaker’s formula is to “add” the refractions at the two surfaces, under the paraxial (small‐angle) approximation. For refraction at a spherical surface one may show that
  (1) n₁/s + n₂/s′ = (n₂ – n₁)/R,
where s is the object distance and s′ the image distance from the surface. (Be careful with sign conventions.)

Now, let the first surface (with radius R) separate air (n₁=1) from glass (n₂=n). If we form the image by refraction on the first surface, using (1) we have

  1/s + n/s₁ = (n – 1)/R          (1a)

Here s is the object distance (assumed large, so that in the thin‐lens approximation we can eventually set s → ∞) and s₁ is the image distance inside the glass.

Now, the light enters the glass and reaches the second surface (with radius R′) where it goes from glass (n₁=n) to air (n₂=1). Again applying (1) (with the appropriate distances measured from the second surface) we have

  n/(–s₁′) + 1/s′ = (1 – n)/R′      (1b)
    or   n/s₁′ – 1/s′ = (n – 1)/R′.

Here s₁′ is the distance from the second surface to the “object” for the second refraction (and one must take proper signs; in the thin lens approximation, one can show that to first order s₁′ ≃ s₁). Combining (1a) and (1b) and using the thin lens assumption (that the thickness is negligible, so that one can identify the intermediate image distances) one finds after some algebra that the power (1/f with f the focal length) of the lens is given by

  1/f = (n – 1) [1/R + 1/R′].

Thus we obtain the well-known Lensmaker’s formula for a thin lens.

──────────────────────────────
Part (b): Achromatic Doublet Condition

When two lenses made of different glasses (here “crown” and “flint”) are cemented together, we can “tune” the dispersive effects so that the overall focal length is independent of wavelength (to first order in the wavelength spread). If the focal lengths of the individual components are f_c (crown) and f_t (flint), then their powers add. However, the refractive index in each glass varies with wavelength (with dispersion characterized by dn/dλ). Let the “dispersion parameter” be defined as

  Δ = (1/(n̄ – 1)) (dn/dλ) Δλ,
 
where n̄ is the value of the index at the center of the visible spectrum and Δλ is roughly the spread of wavelengths (about 3000 Å). Then, to first order in wavelength, one finds that the change in the power (1/f) of each element is proportional to Δ, so that the crown and flint glasses experience modifications in their powers given by (Δ_c)/f_c and (Δ_f)/f_t, respectively. For the composite (achromatic) lens the first order dependence on wavelength must cancel; that is, we require

  (Δ_c)/f_c + (Δ_f)/f_t = 0.

This is the condition for achromatism: the change in optical power with wavelength for the crown lens is exactly canceled by that from the flint lens.

──────────────────────────────
Part (c): Signs for the Achromatic System

In an achromatic doublet the goal is to obtain a net converging lens (with an overall positive focal length). We are given that

  Δ_c = 0.0169  (crown glass)   and  Δ_f = 0.0384  (flint glass).

Since both Δ’s are positive numbers, the cancellation condition

  (Δ_c)/f_c + (Δ_f)/f_t = 0      (2)
  ⟹ (Δ_c)/f_c = – (Δ_f)/f_t

tells us that the two powers (1/f) must have opposite signs. This immediately tells us that if we choose the crown glass lens to have positive focal length (that is, it is converging, so that f_c > 0), then the flint glass lens must have negative focal length (f_t < 0, i.e. diverging). In other words, to construct a converging achromatic lens one must cement together a converging crown lens and a diverging flint lens.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

Thus, we have shown:

(a) A thin lens obeys the Lensmaker’s formula
  1/f = (n – 1)[1/R + 1/R′].

(b) To cancel the chromatic dispersion, the powers of the crown and flint components must satisfy
  (Δ_c)/f_c + (Δ_f)/f_t = 0.

(c) Since Δ_c and Δ_f are both positive, the cancellation condition implies that if the crown lens is converging (f_c > 0), then the flint lens must be diverging (f_t < 0). This is the required condition to obtain a converging achromatic doublet.

Final answer in boxed form:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{l}
\text{(a) } \frac{1}{f} = (n-1)\left(\frac{1}{R} + \frac{1}{R'}\right). \\
\text{(b) Achromatism requires } \frac{\Delta_c}{f_c} + \frac{\Delta_f}{f_t} = 0. \\
\text{(c) Since } \Delta_c, \Delta_f >0, \text{ one must have } f_c>0 \text{ (converging crown) and } f_t<0 \text{ (diverging flint).}
\end{array}
}
\]

We can analyze the experiment step by step. The setup is that a distant (point) source illuminates an opaque screen that contains two narrow, parallel slits. A lens is placed after the slits and brings the transmitted light to a focus. In the focal (Fourier) plane of the lens, the angular spectrum of the light becomes the spatial distribution, and we can directly observe the interference pattern.

────────────────────────────
Step (a): The Interference Pattern

For a coherent (point) source, the two slits radiate light that interferes at the focal plane. (If the slits are narrow enough, you may also see the single‐slit diffraction envelope; however, here we emphasize the double‐slit interference.) At a point in the focal plane a lateral displacement x corresponds to an angle given approximately by θ ≈ x/f, where f is the lens focal length. The phase difference between light from the two slits is

  δ = (2π/λ) d sinθ ≈ (2πd/λ)(x/f).

Thus the intensity as a function of position is

  I(x) = I₀ cos²(π d x/(λ f))     (assuming equal amplitudes).

A rough sketch of I(x) versus x will show a series of regularly spaced bright (maxima) and dark (minima) fringes with the central maximum at x = 0.

────────────────────────────
Step (b): Effect of Moving the Slits Further Apart

Increasing the distance d between the slits has a direct effect on the fringe spacing. Notice that the spacing between adjacent maxima (or minima) Δx is given by

  Δx = (λ f)/d.

So if d increases, Δx decreases – meaning the fringes become “closer together” or more tightly spaced. A second graph would show the same oscillatory cosine-squared behavior but with compressed fringe spacing (i.e. more fringes per unit length).

────────────────────────────
Step (c): Effect of a Finite-Sized (Extended) Source

A distant point source gives perfect spatial coherence across the slits. However, if the source has a finite size so that it subtends an angle at the lens, then different parts of the source will have slightly different angles of incidence. In effect, each point on the extended source produces its own fringe pattern that is shifted relative to the others. When these shifted patterns are superposed, the sharp interference fringes become “washed out” (i.e. the fringe visibility or contrast is reduced). A third graph would show that while there is still an underlying fringe structure, its contrast is diminished and in the limit the pattern might just become a smooth envelope rather than distinct bright and dark fringes.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer

(a) The interference pattern in the focal plane is a series of evenly spaced bright and dark fringes with intensity given by 
  I(x) ∝ cos²(π d x/(λ f)).  
(b) If the slits are moved further apart (increasing d), the fringe spacing Δx = (λ f)/d decreases (fringes become closer together).  
(c) Increasing the size of the source (making it extended) causes a superposition of many slightly shifted fringe patterns, which washes out the contrast, so that the fringes become less pronounced.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Box

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & I(x) \propto \cos^2\left(\frac{\pi d\, x}{\lambda f}\right)\quad\text{(a series of regular bright and dark fringes)},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & \text{Increasing } d\text{ leads to } \Delta x = \frac{\lambda f}{d}\text{ decreasing, so fringes are more closely spaced},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad & \text{An extended source produces a superposition of shifted fringe patterns, thereby reducing the fringe contrast (washed out fringes)}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We start by noting that the glass sheet is a thin film with its two surfaces giving rise to two reflected waves that can interfere. Consider a beam of monochromatic light normally incident on a film (with index n = 1.50 and thickness t = 1.2 × 10⁻⁶ m) in air (n ≈ 1).

Step 1. Determine the phase shifts upon reflection.
• When light reflects from the first surface (air to glass), it reflects off a medium of higher refractive index. This reflection introduces a phase shift of π (i.e. a half‐wavelength shift).
• The light that is transmitted into the film then reflects off the second surface (glass to air) because it is going from a higher n to a lower n. This reflection does not introduce any extra phase shift.

Step 2. Calculate the optical path difference.
The beam that reflects from the second interface travels an extra distance through the film twice (down and up) so that its extra optical path is 2n t. In terms of phase (with vacuum wavelength λ) this gives an added phase (apart from reflection phase shifts) of

  (2π/λ) (2 n t) = 4π n t/λ.

Step 3. Write the interference condition.
The two reflected beams will interfere constructively when the total phase difference between them is an even multiple of π. Because the wave reflecting from the first interface already has an extra π shift, the condition for constructive interference is

  (phase from extra path) – π = 2π m           (for m = 0, 1, 2, …)

That is,
  4π n t/λ – π = 2π m.

Step 4. Solve for λ.
First, add π to both sides:

  4π n t/λ = 2π m + π = π (2m + 1).

Divide both sides by π and solve for λ:

  4 n t/λ = 2m + 1   ⟹  λ = (4 n t)/(2m + 1).

Step 5. Substitute numerical values.
We have:
  n = 1.50   t = 1.20 × 10⁻⁶ m,
so  4 n t = 4 × 1.50 × 1.20×10⁻⁶ m = 7.2×10⁻⁶ m.

Thus, the constructive interference wavelengths are given by

  λ = (7.2×10⁻⁶ m)/(2m + 1).

Step 6. Identify the wavelengths in the visible range (400 nm ≤ λ ≤ 700 nm).
Let’s compute a few values:

• For m = 0:
  λ = (7.2×10⁻⁶)/(1) = 7.2×10⁻⁶ m = 7200 nm (far infrared, not visible).

• For m = 1:
  λ = (7.2×10⁻⁶)/(3) = 2.4×10⁻⁶ m = 2400 nm (infrared).

• For m = 2:
  λ = (7.2×10⁻⁶)/(5) = 1.44×10⁻⁶ m = 1440 nm (infrared).

• For m = 3:
  λ = (7.2×10⁻⁶)/(7) ≈ 1.03×10⁻⁶ m = 1030 nm (infrared).

• For m = 4:
  λ = (7.2×10⁻⁶)/(9) ≈ 8.0×10⁻⁷ m = 800 nm (just beyond the visible red).

• For m = 5:
  λ = (7.2×10⁻⁶)/(11) ≈ 6.545×10⁻⁷ m = 654.5 nm (red).

• For m = 6:
  λ = (7.2×10⁻⁶)/(13) ≈ 5.538×10⁻⁷ m = 553.8 nm (green-yellow).

• For m = 7:
  λ = (7.2×10⁻⁶)/(15) = 4.80×10⁻⁷ m = 480 nm (blue).

• For m = 8:
  λ = (7.2×10⁻⁶)/(17) ≈ 4.235×10⁻⁷ m = 423.5 nm (violet).

• For m = 9:
  λ = (7.2×10⁻⁶)/(19) ≈ 3.789×10⁻⁷ m = 378.9 nm (just below the visible range).

Thus, inside the visible region (400 nm to 700 nm), the most intensely reflected wavelengths are approximately:
  654 nm, 554 nm, 480 nm, and 424 nm.

\boxed{ \lambda \approx 654\,\text{nm},\, 554\,\text{nm},\,480\,\text{nm},\, 424\,\text{nm} }
\]

We are given a two‐slit system with coherent light of wavelength λ. With one slit open the measured intensity is I₀. (Thus, the field amplitude from one slit is proportional to √I₀.) When both slits are open the fields add coherently. We now analyze the situation step by step.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (a): Two-slit Interference

At a distance large compared with the slit separation a, the path‐difference to the detector at an angle θ relative to the normal is approximately
  δ = a sinθ.
Thus, the phase difference between the two fields is
  ϕ = k (a sinθ) = (2π/λ) (a sinθ).

Since each slit (when open alone) produces an intensity I₀ (and hence a field amplitude √I₀), the total field when both slits are open is

  E_total ∝ √I₀ e^(iϕ₁) + √I₀ e^(iϕ₂).

Choosing a reference so that ϕ₁ = 0 and ϕ₂ = ϕ, we have

  E_total ∝ √I₀ [1 + e^(iϕ)].

The resulting intensity (proportional to the square of the modulus of the field) is
  I(θ) ∝ I₀ |1 + e^(iϕ)|².

Calculate the modulus:
  |1 + e^(iϕ)|² = (1 + e^(iϕ)) (1 + e^(–iϕ)) = 2 + 2 cosϕ.
Thus,
  I(θ) = I₀ [2 + 2 cosϕ] = 2I₀ [1 + cos((2πa sinθ)/λ)].

It is often more convenient to write this in the form of a squared cosine. Recall that
  1 + cos(ϕ) = 2 cos²(ϕ/2).
Thus, the intensity pattern becomes

  I(θ)= 2I₀ · 2 cos²((ϕ)/2) = 4I₀ cos²((πa sinθ)/λ).

This is the well‐known double-slit interference pattern: a series of fringes oscillating between zero intensity and a maximum of 4I₀ with angular spacing roughly given by

  Δθ ~ λ/a.

Sketch:
 • At θ = 0, cos²(0)=1 so I(0)=4I₀.
 • As θ increases, the cosine squared produces rapid oscillations between 0 and 1.
 • The fringes are equally spaced (in sinθ space) with zeros when (πa sinθ)/λ = (n+½)π (n = 0, 1, 2, …).

───────────────────────────── 
Step (b): Jittering Slit Spacing

Now assume the slit spacing is not fixed but “jitters” so that a becomes a random variable with a Gaussian distribution centered at 𝑎̄ (with 𝑎̄ ≫ Δ) and having a width Δ (with Δ ≫ λ). Because the jitter occurs on a timescale long compared to the optical period but short compared to the detector response time, the detector records an intensity averaged over the distribution of slit spacings.

For a given slit spacing a, the intensity is

  I(θ; a)= 2I₀ [1 + cos((2πa sinθ)/λ)].

Averaging over the Gaussian distribution of a, the constant term 1 remains unchanged, but the interference term becomes “washed‐out” due to the random phase:
  ⟨cos((2πa sinθ)/λ)⟩ = cos((2π𝑎̄ sinθ)/λ) exp[–½(2πΔ sinθ/λ)²].

Thus, the averaged intensity is

  I_avg(θ)= 2I₀ { 1 + cos((2π𝑎̄ sinθ)/λ) · exp[–(2πΔ sinθ/λ)²/2] }.

Now note the condition Δ ≫ λ. Except for very small θ (where sinθ is so small that the exponential factor is ≈1), even a modest value of θ makes (2πΔ sinθ/λ)≫ 1 so that the exponential, exp[–(2πΔ sinθ/λ)²/2], is strongly suppressed. Thus, for nearly all angles θ the interference (cosine) term is effectively zero. In other words, the fast fluctuation of the slit separation “washes out” the interference fringes. What remains is

  I_avg(θ) ≈ 2I₀  (for most θ ≠ 0).

Sketch:
 • Instead of an oscillating fringe pattern with a maximum of 4I₀ and minima of 0, the detected intensity is nearly constant at 2I₀ over almost the entire angular range.
 • There may be a very narrow central region (θ very near 0) where the interference is not completely averaged out, but since Δ ≫ λ this region is extremely narrow and practically unobservable in a typical setup.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers in LaTeX Boxed Form

(a) When both slits are open, the intensity as a function of angle θ is

  I(θ)= 4I₀ cos²((πa sinθ)/λ).

(b) When the slit separation jitters with a Gaussian distribution of width Δ (with 𝑎̄ ≫ Δ ≫ λ), the time-averaged intensity becomes

  I_avg(θ)= 2I₀ {1 + cos((2π𝑎̄ sinθ)/λ) exp[–(2πΔ sinθ/λ)²/2]},

which, because Δ ≫ λ, is nearly constant at 2I₀ for nearly all θ.

Thus, the final results are:

  (a) I(θ)= 4I₀ cos²((πa sinθ)/λ),
  (b) I_avg(θ) ≈ 2I₀ (nearly constant; the interference fringes are washed out).

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer in LaTeX:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & I(\theta)= 4I_0\cos^2\left(\frac{\pi a\sin\theta}{\lambda}\right) \\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & I_{\text{avg}}(\theta)=2I_0\left\{ 1+\cos\left(\frac{2\pi\bar{a}\sin\theta}{\lambda}\right)
\exp\left[-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{2\pi\Delta\sin\theta}{\lambda}\right)^2\right]\right\}\approx 2I_0\text{ (for most } \theta\text{)}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We will show step‐by‐step how one may arrive at an answer. One acceptable answer was to “build” the partially polarized beam as the incoherent sum of a completely “polarized” part (which – though it may be elliptical – can always be written in the form of two orthogonal intensities) and an unpolarized part. (Any answer equivalent to the answers given below is correct.)

In the following we use I₀ as a “unit” intensity. (Also note that the transmitted intensity through a perfect (loss‐less) polarizer is obtained by projecting the “polarized part” onto the transmission direction and by taking one half of the unpolarized light.)

────────────────────────────
Step 1. Description of the beam before the quarter‐wave plate

Suppose that the incident beam has a total intensity 
  I_total = I_pol + I_u,
with a completely polarized part of intensity I_pol and an unpolarized part of intensity I_u. (The “degree of polarization” is then p = I_pol/I_total.)

When the beam is sent through a linear polarizer with its transmission axis at an angle θ from the “preferred” direction (to be determined) the transmitted intensity is the sum of the contributions from the polarized and unpolarized parts. In our treatment we write

  I(θ) = (from polarized part) + (from unpolarized part).

If the polarized part were completely “linear” (that is, of the form E = [a, 0] in some basis) then one would have by Malus’s law for that part
  I_pol(θ) = I_pol cos²(θ – ψ),
where ψ is the “direction of polarization” of the polarized part. In addition, the unpolarized light always gives a contribution (half its intensity) regardless of the orientation. (That is, an ideal polarizer transmits one–half of the intensity of unpolarized light.) Therefore we write

  I(θ) = I_pol cos²(θ – ψ) + I_u/2.
                  (1)

Now we are told that when the transmission axis is along x the transmitted intensity is maximum:
  I(0) = 1.5 I₀.
Also, when the transmission axis is along y (i.e. at 90°) the transmitted intensity is minimum:
  I(90°) = I₀.

Since the maximum is obtained when the polarizer is aligned with the polarization direction of the polarized part, we may take

  ψ = 0.
Then Eq. (1) becomes

  I(θ) = I_pol cos²θ + I_u/2.
In particular,
  I(0) = I_pol + I_u/2 = 1.5 I₀,  (2)
  I(90°)= 0 + I_u/2 = I₀.  (3)

From (3) we immediately read
  I_u/2 = I₀  ⟹  I_u = 2 I₀.
Then (2) gives
  I_pol = 1.5 I₀ – I_u/2 = 1.5 I₀ – I₀ = 0.5 I₀.
Thus the total intensity is
  I_total = I_pol + I_u = 0.5 I₀ + 2I₀ = 2.5 I₀.
In our picture the polarized part is only 20% of the total (0.5I₀/2.5I₀) and the unpolarized part is 80%. (In what follows we shall see that after the quarter–wave plate the numbers change: the reason will be that the “polarized part” of the beam was not in fact entirely “linear” but rather elliptically polarized.)

────────────────────────────
(a) Intensity for an Arbitrary Analyzer Angle

Equation (1) now becomes

  I(θ) = I_pol cos²θ + I_u/2.
Using the numbers we obtained we have

  I(θ) = 0.5 I₀ cos²θ + I₀.
That is, one acceptable answer is

  I(θ) = I₀ + 0.5 I₀ cos²θ.
It is important to note that the answer depends only on the extreme intensities: the general result may be written as

  I(θ) = I(90°) + [I(0°) – I(90°)] cos²θ.
Thus the answer does not depend on what the separate values of I_pol and I_u are (i.e. “what fraction is unpolarized”) but only on the measured maximum and minimum.
  
────────────────────────────
(b) After the Quarter–wave Plate

Now the beam is passed through a quarter–wave plate whose fast and slow axes are along x and y. A quarter–wave plate introduces a phase shift of 90° between the x and y components. (Its effect on incoherent unpolarized light is simply to leave its intensity unchanged.)

A key fact is that if the polarized part of the beam were completely linear (say along x) then the QWP would do nothing (because the light is already along one of its axes). However, the clue is that after the quarter–wave plate the maximum transmitted intensity through the polarizer occurs when its axis is at 30° to the x–axis. This tells us that the fully polarized part of the beam was NOT fully “linear” to begin with but was in fact elliptically polarized.

Let the polarized part be described by a Jones vector (up to an overall phase) of the form

  (E_x, E_y) = (a, b e^(iδ)).
Then the intensity transmitted by a linear polarizer at an angle θ is proportional to

  |a cosθ + b e^(iδ) sinθ|² = a² cos²θ + b² sin²θ + 2ab cosθ sinθ cosδ.
Now, before the QWP we are told that the maximum intensity occurs for θ = 0 (i.e. along x) and the minimum for θ = 90° (along y). For these to be extrema the cross term must vanish. (A short calculation shows that this forces cosδ = 0, i.e. δ = ±90°.) (Any answer in which one takes δ = ±π/2 is acceptable; here we choose δ = –π/2.) Then before the QWP the polarized part gives

  I_pol(0) = a²  and  I_pol(90°) = b².
We already have from part (a) that
  a² = I(0) – I_u/2 = 1.5I₀ – I₀ = 0.5I₀,
  b² = I(90°) – I_u/2 = I₀ – I₀ = 0.
At first glance one might then think that the light is purely linear along x. But then there would be no change after a quarter–wave plate. The fact that the maximum after the QWP appears at 30° tells us that our assumption in part (a) must be refined. (In many experiments one finds that the beam is “partially elliptically polarized” so that the measured intensities when analysing the beam in the x,y directions are not the full story. In such a case one must allow that even though the transmitted intensities in the x and y directions retain the values 1.5I₀ and I₀, the complex amplitudes must be taken as)

  a² = 1.5 I₀ – I_u/2  and  b² = I(90°)_pol = I₀ – I_u/2,
with a² > b².
In other words, we write
  a² = 1.5 I₀ – I_u/2  ,  b² = I₀ – I_u/2.
But we already obtained I_u = 2 I₀ if one assumed a fully linear state. To allow a nonzero b we must suppose that the measured analyzer intensities come from an incoherent superposition of a polarized state (of total intensity I_pol) and an unpolarized state (of intensity I_u) with

  I_pol + I_u = 2.5 I₀.
Let us now denote the “true” values of a² and b² in the polarized part by

  a² = 1.5I₀ – I_u/2  and  b² = I₀ – I_u/2.
Then one obviously has

  I_pol = a² + b² = (1.5I₀ + I₀) – I_u = 2.5I₀ – I_u.
That is, the fraction of polarized light is p = (2.5I₀ – I_u)/(2.5I₀).

Now comes the extra information provided by the QWP and the observation that after the QWP the maximum transmitted intensity (when the polarizer is rotated) occurs when its transmission axis is at 30° to x. A quarter–wave plate with axes along x and y takes the Jones vector (a, b e^(–iπ/2)) into
  (a, b e^(–iπ/2+ iπ/2)) = (a, b)
if we choose δ = –π/2. That is, it “undoes” the phase difference so that the previously elliptical beam becomes linearly polarized but not along x in general. In fact, the new linear polarization direction θ₀ is given by

  tan θ₀ = b/a.
We are told that the maximum occurs when the analyzer is at 30°; hence
  tan 30° = 1/√3 = b/a  ⟹  b²/a² = 1/3.
But we already know that before the QWP (and thus also after it) the quantities a² and b² are given by

  a² = 1.5I₀ – I_u/2,  b² = I₀ – I_u/2.
Therefore,

  (I₀ – I_u/2)/(1.5I₀ – I_u/2) = 1/3.
Solve this equation:
  3(I₀ – I_u/2) = 1.5I₀ – I_u/2.
Multiply out:
  3I₀ – (3/2) I_u = 1.5 I₀ – 0.5 I_u.
Then, rearrange:
  3I₀ – 1.5I₀ = (3/2 I_u – 1/2 I_u)  ⟹  1.5I₀ = I_u.
Thus, the unpolarized intensity is

  I_u = 1.5 I₀.
Then the polarized intensity is

  I_pol = 2.5I₀ – I_u = 2.5I₀ – 1.5I₀ = I₀.
And
  a² = 1.5I₀ – I_u/2 = 1.5I₀ – 0.75I₀ = 0.75I₀,
  b² = I₀ – I_u/2 = I₀ – 0.75I₀ = 0.25I₀.
Thus the degree of polarization (i.e. the fraction of the total intensity which is polarized) is

  p = I_pol/(I_pol + I_u) = I₀/(I₀ + 1.5I₀) = 1/2.5 = 0.4,
or 40% polarized and 60% unpolarized.

After the QWP the polarized part becomes linearly polarized along the direction given by

  tan θ₀ = b/a = √0.25/√0.75 = 1/√3,
so that

  θ₀ = 30°.
That is why the maximum transmitted intensity (of the polarized light) now occurs when the analyzer is at 30° to x. When the analyzer is exactly aligned with this new polarization, the polarized part is transmitted completely. Also, the unpolarized part always contributes half of its intensity. Therefore, the maximum transmitted intensity after the QWP is

  I_max = (polarized part) + (half the unpolarized part)
       = I_pol + I_u/2
       = I₀ + 1.5I₀/2
       = I₀ + 0.75I₀
       = 1.75 I₀.
────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) Before any quarter–wave plate the transmitted intensity when the analyzer is at an angle θ from the x–axis is given by

  I(θ) = I(90°) + [I(0°) – I(90°)] cos²θ = I₀ + 0.5I₀ cos²θ.
This answer does not depend separately on the fractions of polarized and unpolarized light but only on the measured maximum and minimum.

(b) When the beam is passed through a quarter–wave plate (with its axes along x and y) and then through the linear analyzer, the maximum transmitted intensity (attained when the analyzer is at 30° to x) is

  I_max = 1.75 I₀,
and the fraction of the incident intensity which is unpolarized is

  I_u/(I_pol+I_u) = 1.5I₀/2.5I₀ = 0.6  (60% unpolarized).

Thus, one acceptable final answer is:

  (a) I(θ) = I₀ + 0.5 I₀ cos²θ   (b) I_max = 1.75 I₀  and 60% of the incident intensity is unpolarized.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Boxed Format

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad I(\theta) &= I(90^\circ) + \Bigl[I(0^\circ)-I(90^\circ)\Bigr]\cos^2\theta 
=\; I_0+0.5\,I_0\cos^2\theta, \\
\text{(b)}\quad I_{\max} &= 1.75\,I_0,\quad\text{and the unpolarized fraction is } \frac{1.5\,I_0}{2.5\,I_0}=0.6.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to study a three‐slit system where each slit is of width a and the centers of adjacent slits are separated by a distance d. (Thus the left slit is at x = –d, the middle slit at x = 0, and the right slit at x = +d.) In this system the wave passing through the middle slit is passed through a filter which adds a 180° (π radians) phase shift. (The slit widths, however, are small enough so that each slit produces the usual single–slit diffraction envelope.) An incident plane wave (of wavelength λ) strikes the system. We will find:

 (a) The angle θ for the first diffraction minimum (i.e. from the single–slit envelope),
 (b) The angle θ for the first interference minimum (the first zero of the interference pattern due to the three slits with the extra π shift in the middle),
 (c) The angle θ for the first interference maximum (i.e. the first bright fringe aside from the central maximum).

Let us analyze each in turn.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (a): First Diffraction Minimum

Each slit (of width a) produces a diffraction envelope given by a well–known condition. (The extra phase of the middle slit does not change its single‐slit envelope.)

The minima of the single–slit diffraction pattern occur when
  a sin θ = m λ,  m = ±1, ±2, …
Thus, the first (i.e. m = 1) diffraction minimum is at

  a sinθ = λ  ⟹  sinθ = λ/a.
───────────────────────────── 
Step (b): First Interference Minimum

Now we consider the interference between the three slits. (Here we ignore the diffraction envelope and assume that each slit produces the same amplitude.) Choose the phase at the central slit (located at x = 0) as our reference. However, because the middle slit has a π phase shift, its contribution will come with a factor of –1.

Also, due to the path‐length differences, the left and right slits acquire an extra phase. In the far field (Fraunhofer approximation) the additional phase for a slit at position x is

  ϕ = k x sinθ = (2π/λ)x sinθ.
Thus we have:
 Left slit (x = –d): phase = –(2π d sinθ)/λ,
 Middle slit (x = 0): phase = π    (because of the filter),
 Right slit (x = +d): phase = +(2π d sinθ)/λ.

Let δ be defined as
  δ = (2π/λ)d sinθ.
Then the complex amplitudes (taking each amplitude as E₀) are:
 Left: E₀ exp(–iδ)
 Middle: E₀ exp(iπ) = –E₀
 Right: E₀ exp(iδ)

Thus the total complex amplitude is

  E_total = E₀[exp(–iδ) – 1 + exp(iδ)].
Recall that exp(–iδ) + exp(iδ) = 2 cos δ so that

  E_total = E₀ [2 cos δ – 1].

The intensity (ignoring the overall envelope) is proportional to |E_total|², i.e.,
  I(θ) ∝ [2 cosδ – 1]².

An interference minimum occurs when the amplitude is zero:

  2 cosδ – 1 = 0  ⟹  cosδ = 1/2.
The smallest positive solution for δ is

  δ = π/3    (since cos(π/3) = 1/2).
But since δ = (2π/λ)d sinθ, we have

  (2π/λ)d sinθ = π/3  ⟹  sinθ = (π/3)(λ/(2π d)) = λ/(6d).

Thus the first interference minimum occurs at

  sinθ = λ/(6d).
───────────────────────────── 
Step (c): First Interference Maximum

The interference maxima are the angles at which the resultant amplitude |E_total| is greatest. We found

  E_total = E₀(2 cosδ – 1).
One way to find extrema is to set the derivative (with respect to δ) equal to zero. However, note that because our expression is a simple cosine function (linearly shifted), we can simply test the values at which sinδ = 0 (which are the extrema) and then pick the case giving a maximum in |E_total|.

For sinδ = 0, we have δ = nπ, where n is an integer. Then
  E_total = E₀ (2 cos(nπ) – 1).
Now, consider n even and odd:
 For n even (n = 0, 2, …): cos(nπ) = 1, so
  E_total = E₀ (2 – 1) = E₀.
 For n odd (n = 1, 3, …): cos(nπ) = –1, so
  E_total = E₀ (–2 – 1) = –3E₀; the magnitude is 3E₀.

Thus the “brightest” fringe (the maximum in intensity) has an amplitude three times that of a single slit. (Indeed, note that at θ = 0, i.e. δ = 0, we get only E_total = E₀ because the contributions 1 – 1 + 1 yield 1.) Therefore, the first (i.e. lowest angle) interference maximum actually occurs when n = 1, i.e.,
  δ = π.
Recalling δ = (2π/λ)d sinθ, we have

  (2π/λ)d sinθ = π  ⟹  sinθ = (π)(λ/(2π d)) = λ/(2d).

Thus the first interference maximum (the first bright fringe aside from the central one) occurs at

  sinθ = λ/(2d).
───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

(a) The first diffraction minimum is given by
  a sinθ = λ ⟹ sinθ = λ/a.

(b) The first interference minimum is given by
  (2π/λ)d sinθ = π/3 ⟹ sinθ = λ/(6d).

(c) The first interference maximum is given by
  (2π/λ)d sinθ = π ⟹ sinθ = λ/(2d).

In summary, the answers are:

  (a) sinθ = λ/a,  (b) sinθ = λ/(6d),  (c) sinθ = λ/(2d).

Now we provide the final boxed answers in LaTeX:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}&\quad a\sin\theta=\lambda \quad \Longrightarrow\quad \sin\theta=\frac{\lambda}{a},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}&\quad \frac{2\pi}{\lambda}d\sin\theta=\frac{\pi}{3} \quad \Longrightarrow\quad \sin\theta=\frac{\lambda}{6d},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}&\quad \frac{2\pi}{\lambda}d\sin\theta=\pi \quad \Longrightarrow\quad \sin\theta=\frac{\lambda}{2d}\,.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We are asked to compare “short‐wavelength” optics (roughly 100 Å, i.e. extreme ultraviolet [EUV] and soft X‐ray regimes) with “visible‐wavelength” optics (roughly 5000 Å) in four respects. In the discussion below we explain, step by step, the physical reasons why the same “optical” element behaves very differently in these two wavelength regimes.

───────────────────────────── 
1. (a) Use of Lenses

• Visible (~5000 Å): In the visible, many glasses and plastics are quite transparent. Their refractive indices differ from unity by of order 0.2–0.5. Thus, a lens can be made to bend light appreciably to form images. It is quite natural to use curved lenses in eyeglasses, cameras, telescopes, etc.

• Short-wavelength (≈100 Å): In the EUV and soft X‐ray regimes, almost no material is “transparent” in the conventional sense. (In fact, for X–rays the real part of the refractive index is almost exactly 1, and absorption is very high.) Therefore no bulk piece of glass can be used to focus or “bend” the beam by refraction. (In special cases one might look at diffractive elements such as zone plates—but these are not “lenses” in the conventional refractive sense.) 

Thus, typical refractive lenses are not feasible at wavelengths near 100 Å.

───────────────────────────── 
2. (b) Use of Mirrors

• Visible (~5000 Å): In the visible the reflectivity of metal or dielectric layers at normal (or near–normal) incidence is very good, so one may use normal–incidence mirrors (for example, silver– or aluminum–coated mirrors) to form images. 

• Short-wavelength (≈100 Å): At these wavelengths the reflectivity of any material for normal‐incidence light is extremely low because the light penetrates a short distance before being absorbed. To obtain any significant reflection one must work at grazing incidence (light nearly parallel to the surface) or use specially designed multilayer coatings (which use constructive interference effects) to enhance the reflectivity over a narrow band. 

Thus, for EUV/soft X–ray optics one is forced to use grazing–incidence designs (or special multilayer mirrors) whereas standard mirrors work well in the visible.

───────────────────────────── 
3. (c) Chromatic Resolving Power of Gratings of Fixed Width

Recall that the resolving power of a diffraction grating is given (in the ideal case) by
  R = λ/Δλ = mN,
where m is the diffraction order and N is the total number of grooves illuminated. For a grating of fixed physical width, one can—in principle—pack many more grooves if the ruling period is very small. However, in practice the design is subject to additional constraints:

• Visible (~5000 Å): In this range, the groove spacings are chosen so that a sufficient number of grooves is illuminated and efficient diffraction in the desired order is obtained. Normal–incidence geometry is available so the entire physical width is used, and high resolving powers can be achieved.

• Short-wavelength (≈100 Å): Although one might favor a very fine ruling to “match” the short wavelength (so that many grooves are present on a given grating width), practical problems arise. The grating must now also be used in a grazing–incidence configuration to achieve any reflection. In such cases the effective “projected” width is reduced; in addition, manufacturing extremely fine and uniform grooves over a large area becomes more challenging. Thus, although in theory one could have a very high resolving power (because many grooves fit in the physical width), in practice the efficiency and the effective number of illuminated grooves are reduced relative to a visible–light grating.

In summary, while the ideal formula R = mN holds in both cases, the technical implementation (and the effective use of the grating’s width) makes high chromatic resolving power harder to attain at 100 Å than in the visible.

───────────────────────────── 
4. (d) Minimum Resolvable Angular Separation of an Image–Forming System of Fixed Diameter

A diffraction–limited system (for example a telescope) forms images with an angular resolution given roughly by the Rayleigh criterion:
  θ ~ λ/D,
where D is the effective diameter of the aperture.

• Visible (~5000 Å): For a given aperture, say D, the minimum angular separation that can be resolved is proportional to 5000 Å (≈500 nm).

• Short-wavelength (≈100 Å): With the same aperture the minimum resolvable angle would be roughly 100 Å/ D. Since 100 Å (10 nm) is 50 times smaller than 5000 Å, the diffraction–limit is correspondingly smaller. That is, if one could build perfect optics at 100 Å, a system of fixed diameter would have about 50 times better angular resolution than it would at 5000 Å.

However, it must be recalled that making a high–quality imaging system at EUV or soft X–ray wavelengths is extremely challenging (because of the need to work at grazing incidence and the difficulty in fabricating highly polished surfaces), so the theoretically smaller angular size is not always practically achieved.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer

Thus, to summarize: 

(a) In the visible band refractive lenses are practical because materials have significant refraction and low absorption; at 100 Å there is neither appreciable refraction nor low absorption, so conventional lenses cannot be used.

(b) Whereas mirrors at visible wavelengths may operate at or near normal incidence with high reflectivity, at 100 Å one must use either grazing–incidence mirrors or specialized multilayer mirrors to get any useful reflection.

(c) The ideal grating resolving power (R = mN) is set by the number of grooves illuminated. For a fixed width grating, while finer ruling at 100 Å could in principle yield high resolution, the need for grazing–incidence operation and fabrication difficulties reduce the effective resolving power relative to visible gratings.

(d) Finally, the diffraction–limited angular resolution improves linearly as the wavelength is decreased (θ ~ λ/D), so for an aperture of fixed diameter, a system operating at 100 Å is in principle capable of roughly 50 times better angular resolution than one working at 5000 Å, although in practice the difficulties of EUV optics make this more challenging.

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{l}
\text{(a) Lenses: Visible‐optics use refractive lenses because materials are transparent and have } \\
\quad \text{substantial refractive indices. In contrast, at 100\,\text{\AA}\; all materials are highly absorbing }\\
\quad \text{and virtually non–refractive, so conventional lenses cannot be used.}\\[1mm]
\text{(b) Mirrors: Visible light can be reflected efficiently at normal incidence with simple }\\
\quad \text{metallic coatings, whereas at 100\,\text{\AA}\; mirrors must be used at grazing incidence }\\
\quad \text{or be specially multilayer–coated to obtain significant reflectivity.}\\[1mm]
\text{(c) Gratings: Although the ideal resolving power }R = mN\text{ holds in both regimes, the }\\
\quad \text{need to work in grazing incidence at 100\,\text{\AA}\; (and the fabrication of very fine grooves)}\\
\quad \text{reduces the effective number of grooves compared to visible–optics made under normal incidence.}\\[1mm]
\text{(d) Angular Resolution: The diffraction limit }(\theta \sim \lambda/D)\text{ scales with wavelength; }\\
\quad \text{so an aperture of fixed diameter yields a theoretically 50 times better angular resolution }\\
\quad \text{at 100\,\text{\AA}\; than at 5000\,\text{\AA}, though practical limitations often prevent }\\
\quad \text{fully realizing this advantage.}
\end{array}
}
\]

solution:
The observer’s ability to directly sense interference effects from separated independent pairs of light or sound generators primarily depends on the coherence of the sources and the spatial-temporal overlap of the waves. Interference is only observed when the sources maintain a stable phase relationship—i.e., they are coherent. For light, this coherence is typically achieved with lasers rather than independent, incoherent light sources; for sound, similarly, the sources must be phase-locked or otherwise synchronized. If the independent emitters have random or drifting phases, the interference pattern averages out to a uniform intensity distribution, and no distinct interference effects (such as fringes or beats) will be detectable by an observer.

Additionally, the interference effects can only be observed if the waves from the two separate pairs physically overlap in space and time at the observer’s location, and if the observer’s detection system has sufficient resolution to resolve the resulting pattern. If the sources are arranged so that their emissions do not combine, or if the observer or instrument does not have the requisite spatial or temporal resolution to discern the interference pattern, these effects may not be directly sensed.

Step 1. Understand the situation

In a Young’s double-slit experiment, the interference pattern forms with a central (zero order) maximum located at the position of zero path difference. When a thin film is placed behind one slit, it introduces an extra optical path difference given by

  Δ = (n – 1)t

where
  n = index of refraction of the film,
  t = thickness of the film.

Step 2. Relate the shift to the fringe order

The problem states that the central maximum (zero order fringe) is shifted to the position of the 4th order bright fringe. In a standard interference pattern, bright fringes occur at points where the path difference is an integral number of wavelengths; specifically, the m-th order maximum corresponds to a path difference:

  Δ = mλ

Thus, a shift of the central maximum to the former 4th bright fringe means that the extra path difference introduced by the film is equal to the path difference corresponding to m = 4:

  (n – 1)t = 4λ

Step 3. Substitute the given values

The wavelength of light is given as λ = 5000 Å. Converting to meters:

  λ = 5000 × 10⁻¹⁰ m = 5 × 10⁻⁷ m

The index of refraction is n = 1.2.

Substitute these into the relation:

  (1.2 – 1)t = 4 × (5 × 10⁻⁷ m)

Calculating the left side:

  0.2 t = 2 × 10⁻⁶ m

Step 4. Solve for t

Divide both sides by 0.2:

  t = (2 × 10⁻⁶ m) / 0.2 = 1 × 10⁻⁵ m

Step 5. Final answer

The thickness of the film is 1.0 × 10⁻⁵ meters.

\[\boxed{t = 1.0 \times 10^{-5}\ \text{m}}\]

We start by recalling that an astronomical (or Keplerian) telescope is normally set so that the final rays emerge parallel. This gives a very simple relation between the positions of the two lenses.

Step 1. Converging Eyepiece (Keplerian Telescope)

For an object at infinity the objective (focal length fₒ) produces a real image at its focal plane (distance fₒ from the objective). In the Keplerian telescope the converging eyepiece (with focal length fₑ) is positioned so that this real image lies at its own focal point. (That is, the distance from the objective to the eyepiece is the sum of the focal lengths.) Thus, the length of the telescope is

  L₍conv₎ = fₒ + fₑ.

The angular magnification for the telescope is given by

  M = fₒ/fₑ    ⇔  fₑ = fₒ/M.

So the length becomes

  L₍conv₎ = fₒ + (fₒ/M) = fₒ (1 + 1/M).

Step 2. Diverging Eyepiece (Galilean Telescope)

In the Galilean telescope, the eyepiece is a diverging lens with focal length –f_d (where f_d > 0 is defined in magnitude). The objective still forms a real image a distance fₒ from it, but now the eyepiece is placed so that its (virtual) focal point coincides with that real image. In this case the separation between the lenses is not fₒ + something but rather

  L₍div₎ = fₒ – f_d,

because the negative eyepiece “subtracts” its focal length. The magnification in a Galilean telescope is given (in absolute value) by

  M = fₒ/|f_d| = fₒ/f_d   ⇒  f_d = fₒ/M.

Thus, the length of the Galilean telescope becomes

  L₍div₎ = fₒ – (fₒ/M) = fₒ (1 – 1/M).

Step 3. Ratio of the Lengths

We now have the two lengths expressed as:

  L₍conv₎ = fₒ (1 + 1/M)  and  L₍div₎ = fₒ (1 – 1/M).

Taking the ratio, we get

  L₍conv₎ / L₍div₎ = [1 + 1/M] / [1 – 1/M] = (M + 1) / (M – 1).

Thus, for the same magnification M, a telescope with a converging eyepiece (Keplerian telescope) is (M+1)/(M–1) times as long as the one with a diverging eyepiece (Galilean telescope).

Step 4. Why Use the Longer Telescope?

One might choose the longer Keplerian telescope (with a converging eyepiece) for several reasons. A very important factor is that the converging eyepiece forms a real image, which allows:
 • A wider field of view (important for viewing extended objects).
 • The possibility to place additional optical elements (such as field flatteners or filters) to correct aberrations.
 • Better eye relief in many designs.
These benefits often outweigh the disadvantage of a longer tube for many astronomical and terrestrial observing applications.

Final Answer:
 The ratio of lengths is given by

  L₍conv₎/L₍div₎ = (M + 1)/(M – 1),

and one might choose the longer (Keplerian) telescope because its real image formation allows for a wider field of view and better correction of optical aberrations.

\[
\boxed{\frac{L_{\text{Keplerian}}}{L_{\text{Galilean}}} = \frac{M+1}{M-1}}
\]

We begin by recalling that when light is incident normally on a thin film, the two reflected rays (one from the top surface and one from the bottom surface) interfere. Since the light is reflecting off a medium of higher refractive index (air to film, n_air = 1 to n_film = 1.5) at the top, there is a phase shift of π (which is equivalent to half a wavelength). The reflection at the bottom face (film to air) does not incur a phase shift. In order for the two reflected rays to interfere constructively (maximum reflected intensity), the extra phase difference due to the extra optical path length in the film must compensate for this phase inversion.

Step 1. Calculate the optical path difference:

A ray that penetrates the film travels a distance d into the film and d out of the film, for a total physical distance of 2d. But in the film the wavelength is shortened by a factor of n, so the optical path difference is

  2 n d.

Step 2. Determine the phase shifts:

• The reflection from the top surface acquires an extra phase of π.
• The additional phase (in radians) acquired by traveling an optical path length of 2nd is

  (2π/λ)(2 n d) = (4π n d)/λ.

So the total phase difference, taking into account the half-wave shift, is

  Δϕ = (4π n d)/λ − π.

Step 3. Constructive interference condition:

For the two reflected rays to be in phase (i.e. constructive interference), the phase difference must be an integer multiple of 2π:

  (4π n d)/λ − π = 2π m     (m = 0, 1, 2,...)

Solve for λ:

  (4π n d)/λ = π (2 m + 1)

  λ = (4 n d)/(2 m + 1).

Step 4. Substitute the given values:

We are given n = 1.5 and d = 5000 Å. Thus

  λ = (4 × 1.5 × 5000 Å)/(2 m + 1)
    = (30000 Å)/(2 m + 1).

Step 5. Determine which orders (m) yield wavelengths in the visible range (4000 Å to 7000 Å):

Consider successive integer m-values:
• For m = 0: λ = 30000/1 = 30000 Å  (not in visible)
• For m = 1: λ = 30000/3 = 10000 Å  (not in visible)
• For m = 2: λ = 30000/5 = 6000 Å   (in visible)
• For m = 3: λ = 30000/7 ≈ 4286 Å  (in visible)
• For m = 4: λ = 30000/9 ≈ 3333 Å   (below visible)

Thus, the only two orders that give wavelengths in the visible range are m = 2 and m = 3.

Final Answer:

The intensity of the reflected light is maximum for wavelengths approximately 6000 Å and 4286 Å.

\[
\boxed{\lambda \approx 6000\,\text{\AA}\quad\text{and}\quad\lambda \approx 4286\,\text{\AA}}
\]
